questions.text: According to Jean Piaget’s stages of intellectual development, the concept of reversibility develops in the _______ stage.
questions.solution:
A child develops the concept of reversibility (i.e., events or ideas can be reversed) during the concrete operations stage of intellectual development. As such, a child who has not attained the concrete operation stage i.e. A child still in preoperational stage cannot understand the fact that broken bones can be mended or blood lost can be replaced.

There are 4 stages in the cognitive development stages, through which the thinking process of an individual develops. They are as follows:

Sensorimotor stage (birth–2 years):

  • Starts with "out of sight, out of mind" type of thinking
  • Ends with object permanence (knowing an object exists even though it cannot be seen) and
  • Symbolization (developing mental symbols and words for the objects).

Pre-operational stage (2-7 years):

Thinking without reasoning—intuitive thinking and

  • Only concerned about their own needs and perspective—egocentric thinking
  • Other thinking processes seen are animism, primitive thinking, centration, magical thinking

Concrete operational stage (7-11 years):

  • Start to see things from others perspective ("theory of mind")
  • Thinking is concrete and literal.
  • Develop conservation: understanding that despite changes in shape, the object remains the same, for e.g., when water is transferred from a cup to glass, they understand that it is water only and that the volume is the same.
  • Develop the concept of reversibility: knowing that one thing can turn into another and turn back. e.g.: water and ice
  • Other processes: classification, transitivity.

Formal operational stage (>11 years):

  • Develop abstract thinking, wherein they can generalize or conceptualize
  • Can make a hypothesis and use deductive reasoning

questions.text: Prominent wound contraction is mainly seen in  ____________
questions.solution:
Prominent wound contraction is seen in Secondary healing.

In secondary wound healing, there is more granulation tissue and more accumulation of ECM causing the formation of a large scar. Consequently increased wound contraction by the action of myofibroblasts.

questions.text: Immunohistochemistry for HER2 protein expression is performed in 3 patients with breast carcinoma, with the following results. Which of the following patients should be subjected to fluorescence in-situ hybridization?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferential staining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining. Hence, she should be subjected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm HER2-positive gene amplification status.

The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors:

  • Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed).
  • Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISH

Once HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated with trastuzumab or lapatinib. 

Related Pearl: Newer molecular tests in breast cancer

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy. These are:

  • Oncotype Dx (21-geneassay)
  • Mammaprint (70-gene assay)
  • EndoPredict (12-gene assay)
  • PAM50 (50-gene assay)

Oncotype Dx can only be used in hormone (ER, PR) receptor-positive cancers, while mammaprint can be used in both hormone receptor (ER, PR) positive and hormone receptor-negative cancers. 

These tests are used for T1,2 N0 M0 breast cancers – (node-negative, metastasis-negative). Using these molecular tests, a recurrence score (0 – 100) is calculated.

  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy
  • If the score is high, then chemotherapy should be added

questions.text: Afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control goes to?
questions.solution:
Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).

Increased BP stimulates the baroreceptors which provide negative feedback in response to the increase in blood pressure.

Baroreceptor reflex:

  • Increased BP → stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → excitation of CVLM → inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system
  • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation
  • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BP

NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius

CVC - Cardiovagal centre

CVLM - Caudal ventrolateral medulla

RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla

HR - Heart rate

BP - Blood pressure

Note:-

Baroreceptors are more sensitive to pulsatile pressure than to constant pressure. A decline in pulse pressure without any change in mean pressure decreases the rate of baroreceptor discharge and provokes a rise in systemic blood pressure and tachycardia.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent?
questions.solution: Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. The other three mentioned are systemic mycoses.

questions.text:
A man is rushed to the ER after losing control of his car and crashing into a tree. Examination findings are given below. What is the most likely cause for his presentation?

BP - 190/100 mmHg

Respiratory rate - 22/minute

GCS - 9/15

Temperature - 106.8 °F

Head and neck examination - Minor abrasions over the face

CNS - Quadriparesis. Pupils are 2 mm and unreactive.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pontine haemorrhage. Clinical features of pontine haemorrhage are:

  • Deep coma
  • Quadriparesis and multiple cranial nerve dysfunction
  • Decerebrate rigidity
  • Pin-point pupils
  • Hyperpnea, hyperpyrexia, severe hypertension, and hyperhidrosis

Option A: The presence of hyperpyrexia and pin-point pupils rule out the possibility of spinal cord trauma.

Option B: Morphine poisoning is a differential diagnosis for pin-point pupils. But it leads to slower respiratory rate, not tachypnea.

Option D: In ponto-medullary laceration, medullary involvement would cause respiratory depression, leading to apnea. But here tachypnea is noted.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the medical intensive care unit.  There is a patient admitted there with heart failure. He has low cardiac output with oliguria. Which of the following inotropes would be preferred in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Dopamine is used in the treatment of severe congestive heart failure, particularly in patients with oliguria as it improves renal function.

It is administered at 2–5 mcg/kg/min intravenously. Stimulation of dopaminergic and β-adrenergic receptors produces increased glomerular filtration, heart rate, and contractility.

Other options:

Option A: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α- and β-adrenergic receptors. It increases cardiac contractility but decreases renal perfusion. It is mainly used in anaphylactic shock.

Option B: Norepinephrine is a potent α and β1 agonist, with very little effect on the β2 receptor. It can be used to raise blood pressure in intensive care conditions, but since it decreases the renal blood flow, it is not preferred in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Fenoldopam is an agonist for peripheral D1 receptors and is used to control hypertension.

questions.text: A 45 year old male with recurrent bloody diarrhea came to the hospital. Colonoscopy showed geographical ulcers. Histopathology is given below. Your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Crohn's disease.

In the given history, recurrent bloody diarrhea indicates periods of active disease interrupted by asymptomatic periods. The presence of geographical ulcers indicate the presence of multiple, clearly delineated areas of disease in-between areas of normal mucosa, or skip lesions.

The histopathological image shows transmural inflammation where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted.
All the above features indicate Crohn’s disease to be the diagnosis.

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seashore sign seen in M-mode imaging of the normal lung.

M-mode is defined as the time-motion display of the ultrasound wave along a chosen ultrasound line. With M-Mode, even rapid motions can be displayed, measured, and recorded.

In the M-mode of USG, the motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves', and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing in onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in a normal lung.

Option A: Stratosphere sign or barcode sign is a finding in the M-mode seen as parallel horizontal lines above and below the pleural line. This is seen in pneumothorax.

Option C: There is no named sign called troposphere sign.

Option D: Mirror image artifact is seen when there is a highly reflective surface (eg: Diaphragm) in the path of the primary beam.

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa?
questions.solution:
The given image shows grade III placenta previa. 

Placenta previa refers to the placenta implanted (partially/completely) over the lower uterine segment (over or adjacent to the internal os). Grades of placenta previa are:

  •  Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

They typically present with sudden onset, painless vaginal bleeding. On vulval inspection, bright red blood is seen oozing from the cervical opening. Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is used to confirm the diagnosis and position of the placenta.

Management is dependent on the presentation of the patient. If there is a need for fetal maturity, expectant management (advocated by McAfee and Johnson) is carried out without increasing undue maternal stress. Definitive management by an elective cesarean section.

questions.text: What level of structural organization of a protein is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures viz:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein.

questions.text: An Intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done then?
questions.solution:
Uneventful intraocular lens placement, is not an indication for replacing the IOL. 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

  • Incorrect IOL placed
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

Option C: In the event that secondary catarct develops, it is treated by surgical or laser (Nd:YaG) posterior capsulotomy.

Option D: Presbyopia is a disorder of accomdation seen in old age. It is usually corrected by prescription unifocal or Bifocal or multifocal glasses or contact lenses.

questions.text: The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is:
questions.solution:
The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is unpaired T test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Following a normal vaginal delivery, a 30-year-old woman develops severe postpartum hemorrhage. Over the next 24 hours, she undergoes transfusion of 11 units of pRBCs. She is at risk for all of the following complications except:
questions.solution:
Massive transfusion is defined as transfusion of at least 10 units of red cells in 24 hours or 4 units in 1 hour. Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is a complication of massive blood transfusion.

Blood is anticoagulated with sodium citrate and citric acid. It binds to calcium and magnesium, leading to low levels of both. Citrate is also metabolized to bicarbonate, causing metabolic alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with microscopy showing ragged red fibres is suggestive of MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke).

It is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency. Patients have normal development previously and then present with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke (seizures with focal neurological deficits).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) as shown below.

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Leigh’s disease
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
  • Pearson syndrome

questions.text: During your morning jogging routine, you found a pair of spectacles lying on the sidewalk. The spectacles are shown below. What type of presbyopic lens is present in these spectacles?
questions.solution: The given lens in the image is a typical example of progressive lenses. Progressive lenses are identified as such due to the absence of the line of demarcation on the lens. They are gradually optimized for reading vision, distant vision, and for intermediate vision, such as computer work.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient who was diagnosed with MDR-TB was put on bedaquiline therapy. Which of the following is false about this drug?

MDR-TB :multidrug-resistant tuberculosis
questions.solution:
Bedaquiline does not reduce treatment duration in MDR-TB.

Bedaquiline/ Sirturo is a bactericidal drug that belongs to diarylquinolines. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme ATP synthase in the Mycobacterium. According to the National TB 

Elimination Program (NTEP), it is used as an add-on drug for pulmonary MDR-TB in adults >18 years.

Dosage of bedaquiline:

  • Week 0–2: 400 mg daily
  • Week 3–24: 200 mg thrice a week (with at least 48 hours between doses) 

Adverse effects of bedaquiline include cardiotoxicity (QT prolongation) and hepatotoxicity.

Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the World Health Organization (WHO):

  • Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid
  • Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine
  • Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid (newer add-on drug), ethionamide, p-aminosalicylic acid

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. In patients not treated before and without the extensive disease, a shorter regimen of 6 months intensive phase with bedaquiline and other drugs is used. The other drugs are continued for 5 months-continuation phase. In pregnant women with MDR-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided. 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is typical of a case of hypothyroidism and the diagnosis is myxedema coma, which is a serious complication of hypothyroidism.

Myxedema coma is a part of a larger clinical picture of myxedema crisis. Myxedema crisis refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is often precipitated by the administration of sedatives, antidepressants, hypnotics, anaesthetics, or opioids.

Clinical features of myxedema crisis :

  • Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma).
  • Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs.
  • Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension.
  • Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury
  • A high mortality rate 

Other options: 

Option A: Without a history of or focus of infection, septic shock is unlikely. 

Option B: Cardiogenic shock would present with symptoms of left heart failure i.e. pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, prominence of neck veins, and dyspnea. 

Option D: Hypoglycemia usually presents with sweating, palpitations, and tachycardia

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of distribution of one standard deviation?
questions.solution:
Approximately 68% of a normal distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean. This is as per the empirical rule of a normal distribution.

Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: The instrument used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele is _______
questions.solution:
Sim's speculum is used for assessment of rectocele and cystocele.

The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualisation of the vaginal walls.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Auvard speculum is used during vaginal hysterectomy. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall and has a weighted handle that makes it self-retaining.

The Veda-scope is a recently developed alternative to bivalve speculums. The instrument creates an air tight seal at the vaginal introitus and the vagina is inflated with filtered air. Following inflation, the vaginal walls can be examined and tests such as VIA VILI (Visual inspection with acetic acid and lugol’s iodine) and pap smear can be performed. It also allows for taking pictures with a camera and introducing a light source.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: What are the muscles given below?
questions.solution:
The given muscles are the palmar interossei of the hand.

This can be identified by certain features from the given picture as follows:

  • There are three main muscles present (1st - rudimentary)
  • All those are unipennate
  • They all originate from metacarpal and get inserted into the dorsal digital expansion and the base of the proximal phalanx
Feature Lumbricals Palmar interossei Dorsal interossei
Number of muscles 4 3 (1st - rudimentary) 4
Nature 1 and 2 - unipennate 3 and 4 - bipennate Unipennate Bipennate
Origin The tendon of flexor digitorum profundus 2nd - ulnar side of the metacarpal bone 3rd and 4th - from the radial side of 4th and 5th metacarpal bones Adjacent sides of bones
Insertion Dorsal digital expansion Dorsal digital expansion Dorsal digital expansion
Nerve supply 1 and 2 - median nerve3 and 4 - ulnar nerve Ulnar nerve Ulnar nerve

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/μL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment method in severe twin to twin transfusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS - Quintero stages 2 to 4.

Among the other options, septostomy is seldom done. Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid. Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.

Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and reduced likelihood of recurrence.

Quintero staging:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor bladder
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor bladder
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV—frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—demise of either fetus.

questions.text: The critical path in the flow chart given below includes how many days?
questions.solution:
Critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Here the red line signifies the critical path and it includes 9 days.

Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: A 15-year old child has a mental age of 5 years. He is suffering from ________
questions.solution:
The above child with an IQ between 20 to 35 is suffering from a severe intellectual disability.

So here IQ = (5/15) x 100 = 33.33

A child with IQ of 33.33 will have severe mental retardation.

Related Pearl: Intelligence Quotient

  • Historically, IQ = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age

  • Higher the IQ, the more brilliant is the person.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of feed forward control mechanism?

choices.text: Exercise resulting in heart rate increase

questions.solution:
Exercise resulting in heart rate increase is not an example of feedforward control mechanism. However, thinking about exercise and it resulting in a heart rate increase would be an example of feedforward control mechanism.  

Feedforward control is that which makes an anticipatory or adaptive response without a specific stimulus.  

Temperature control - Thermoregulatory responses are initiated by the hypothalamus before the changes in environmental temperature changes the core body temperature. Thus, shivering in response to cold environment would be an example of feedforward control.

In the cephalic phase of gastric secretion, the thought of food itself and not food per se produces a gastric secretion.

The cerebellum has a feed-forward inhibition that limits the duration of the excitation produced by any given afferent volley.

Related Pearl: Phase of gastric secretion

Phase

% of HCl secretion

Stimuli

Mechanisms

Cephalic

30

Conditioning, smell, taste, chewing

Vagus → Parietal cell

Vagus →Gastrin → Parietal cell

Gastric

Distension

Vagus →Parietal cell

Vagus →Gastrin →Parietal cell
   

Distension of antrum

Gastrin →Parietal cell

All phases

ACh →ECL cell →Histamine

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with a mass protruding from the anterior vaginal wall that appears like grape clusters. Histopathological examination reveals tadpole cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides).

It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is most frequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumors that cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract.

Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. On microscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end resembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumor cells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with neck nodes. Examination of left ear reveals a dull tympanic membrane, deafness and tinnitus. On tympanogram, a Type B curve is obtained. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

The given scenario of neck nodes (cervical lymphadenopathy) in a 70-year-old male (5th -7th decade) with unilateral serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane and Type B tympanogram) are all suggestive of a nasopharyngeal growth, probably carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. It commonly occurs in males in the 5th to 7th decade. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex 
    • CN II - exophthalmos 
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Examination of the ear shows a dull tympanic membrane and audiometry shows a Type B curve due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult suggests nasopharyngeal growth.

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to the involvement of the CN X may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Other options:

Option A: Chronic suppurative otitis media presents with ear discharge and perforation will be seen on examination.

Option B: On otoscopy, a red reflex is seen through the intact tympanic membrane in the glomus tumor. Tumor arising from the floor of the middle ear gives a rising sun appearance.

Option D: The dull tympanic membrane on examination and Type B tympanogram suggest the presence of fluid in the middle ear as the cause for deafness and not sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her baby to the health facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths, morbidities and provide a positive birthing experience.

questions.text: The condition shown below results from an  Aedes aegypti transmitted flaviviral infection during pregnancy. Identify the virus implicated.
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito borne flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti. The symptoms of the infection are similar to dengue and include fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain.

NCDC Delhi and National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

questions.text: BCG vaccine provides protection against which of the following?
questions.solution:
BCG vaccine provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB.

It does not prevent primary infection. More importantly, it does not prevent reactivation of latent pulmonary infection, the principal source of bacillary spread in the community. The impact of BCG vaccination on transmission of mycobacterium tuberculosis is therefore limited.

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management in this patient, is to do USG to measure the cervical length.

In the given clinical scenario the patient has undergone conization which is a risk factor for cervical incompetence. Hence, it is important to measure the cervical length to diagnose cervical incompetence in this patient. If the cervical length is ≤2.5 cm then a cervical cerclage can be performed.

Cervical cerclage (Option B) is performed as the next step in management when the patient presents with ≥2 second trimester pregnancy losses (History based diagnosis of cervical incompetence). Since, the history in this patient is of preterm labour, the first step would still be to do a TVS to measure the cervical length for diagnosing. Cerclage only comes after diagnosis.

Cervical incompetence is one of the important causes second trimester (mid trimester) abortions.

Risk factors for the incompetence include: 

  • Past h/o surgery on cervix such as conization, loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP)
  • Cervical trauma during labour, instrumental delivery

Diagnosis of cervical incompetence in a pregnant female:

  • H/O ≥2 second trimester abortions (history based diagnosis)→ management is by cervical cerclege+progesterone
  • H/O 1 second trimester abortion→ TVS done between 18-24 weeks to measure the cervical length→USG based diagnosis of cervical incompetence is made if there is h/o 1 or more second trimester abortions with TVS showing cervical length ≤2.5 cm.

TVS findings in cervical incompetence include:

  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm (Normal:3-4cm)
  • Shape of cervix becomes U shaped
  • Diameter of internal os ≥ 2cm

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

Nail finding

 Associated systemic condition

Clubbing
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)
  • Mesothelioma
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congenital heart disease, Endocarditis

Koilonychia

Iron-deficiency anemia, hemochromatosis, Raynaud’s disease

Onycholysis

Psoriasis, onychomycosis, hyperthyroidism, sarcoidosis, trauma, amyloidosis

Pitting

Psoriasis, Reiter’s syndrome, Alopecia areata

Beau’s lines

Any severe systemic illness that disrupts nail growth, Raynaud’s disease, pemphigus, trauma

Yellow nail

Lymphedema, pleural effusion, immunodeficiency, bronchiectasis, sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, nephrotic syndrome, thyroiditis, tuberculosis, Raynaud’s disease

Nail Pterygium

Dorsal: Lichen Planus

Ventral: trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus

 

Nail finding

Associated systemic condition

Terry’s (white) nails

Hepatic failure, cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, CHF, hyperthyroidism, malnutrition

Azure lunula

Hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson’s disease), silver poisoning, quinacrine therapy

Half-and-half nails

Specific for renal failure

Muehrcke’s lines

Specific for hypoalbuminemia

Mees’ lines

Arsenic poisoning, Hodgkin’s disease, CHF, leprosy, malaria, chemotherapy, carbon monoxide poisoning, other systemic insults

Dark longitudinal streaks

Melanoma, benign nevus, chemical staining, normal variant in darkly pigmented people

Splinter hemorrhage

Subacute bacterial endocarditis, SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, antiphospholipid syndrome, peptic ulcer disease, malignancies, oral contraceptive use, pregnancy, psoriasis, trauma

Telangiectasia

Rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, dermatomyositis, scleroderma

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles. The image given below shows the vacuolar myopathy seen in McArdle's disease.

Clinical features include poor exercise tolerance, abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%), and a very low blood lactate after exercise

The images given below show myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing (A) Normal muscle and (B) McArdle's disease.

questions.text: SPIKES protocol is for:
questions.solution:
SPIKES protocol is for breaking bad news.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

  • S - setting
  • P - perception
  • I - invitation or information
  • K - knowledge
  • E - empathy
  • S - summarizing or strategizing

Key components of the SPIKES strategy include:

  • Demonstrating empathy
  • Acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings
  • Exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news
  • Providing information about possible interventions

questions.text: A 35 yrs old pregnant female complaining of hearing loss, which aggravated during pregnancy, was sent for tympanometry. Which of the following type of graph will be seen?
questions.solution:
Most probably the patient is suffering from otosclerosis, which is more common in females and aggravated during pregnancy. Type As tympanogram is seen in otosclerosis.

Types of tympanogram:

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to _____
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin, which is an iron efflux channel in the enterocyte.

Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Increased levels of iron
  • Inflammatory cytokines

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis

Hepcidin is encoded by the HAMP gene and its mutations are associated with hereditary hemochromatosis.

questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 40 yr old lady presents with large left parietal convexity meningioma with perilesional edema. She is scheduled for surgery the next day .A senior neurosurgeon asks a house surgeon to write the pre operative  notes for the lady. Which of the following pre op note is wrong?
questions.solution:
Perilesional oedema or vasogenic oedema responds to steroids thus lowering intracranial pressure. Therefore steroids are to be continued and morning dose has to be taken.

Related Pearl: Drugs that can be continued on the day of surgery

  1. Antihypertensive medications (Exceptions are ACE Inhibitors and ARB) 
  2. Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  3. Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  4. Thyroid medications
  5. Eye drops
  6. Heartburn or reflux medications
  7. Narcotic medications
  8. Anticonvulsants
  9. Asthma medications
  10. Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  11. Statins
  12. Levodopa
  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome. 
 

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: A 60 year old chronic smoker presents with gradual worsening of shortness of breath. On examination reveals bilateral extensive wheeze. Pulmonary function test shows FEV1/FVC < 0.7. Which among the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: There is abnormal permanent bronchial dilatation
FEV1 improves on inhalation of albuterol

questions.solution:
The above given clinical case is suggestive of Chronic bronchitis.

There is always ventilation perfusion mismatch in obstructive lung diseases.

As airways close prematurely at high lung volumes, TLC is increased.

FEV1 shows no change on albuterol inhalation in chronic bronchitis, but it is reversible in asthma.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The patient developed pyruvate carboxylase enzyme deficiency.
  • Biotin serves as co-enzyme for the synthesis of several carboxylase enzymes such as:
    • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
    • Pyruvate carboxylase
    • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
    • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase
  • Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white, develops biotin deficiency and as a result deficiency of the carboxylase enzymes. This is because, a protein called, avidin present in the egg-white bind to biotin in the diet, and makes biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption.

questions.text: A 4-week old infant presented to ER with projectile vomiting. Ultrasonography was done which showed Cervix sign and Nipple sign. Probable diagnosis is ______________
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis since cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis on USG.

  • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called Nipple sign.
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: High titers of HLA antibodies are seen in donor plasma
Nulliparous women are the implicated donors
Patient presents with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
In cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI), the implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. It may occur in any recipient.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient WBCs. The WBCs aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. TRALI is one of the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 hours of transfusion. 

Recipient factors that are associated with increased risk of TRALI include

  • smoking
  • chronic alcohol use
  • shock, liver surgery
  • mechanical ventilation with >30 cmH2O pressure support.

Treatment is supportive and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD by parents for a well-baby checkup when you notice the following lesion. They say the lesion has been present since birth and has been decreasing in size. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots.

Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. Therefore, these spots are congenital, and are easily distinguished from the bruises of child abuse. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

They usually fade away during the first year of life, and the parents should be reassured about this.

 Other options:

  • Salmon patch or naevus simplex is small, pink-colored macules that are commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. They are an ill-defined lesion, which develops due to vascular ectasia. (Note: The subungual oil droplets seen in nail psoriasis are also known as salmon patches).
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis is a congenital benign lesion characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules. The pustular lesions last for 2-3 days, while the hyperpigmented macules may last for about 3 months.
  • Harlequin color change is a congenital lesion, usually seen in low-birth-weight infants where half of the body in the dependent portion turns red in color, while the other half of the body is pale. This occurs due to an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. Changing the infant's position causes a reversal of the pattern.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Orphan Annie eye nuclei is a characteristic feature of:
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei is a characteristic feature of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

The nuclei of papillary carcinoma cells contain finely dispersed chromatin, which gives a clear appearance called as ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei.

Papillary carcinoma can also contain concentrically calcified structures called as psammoma bodies.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Fingerprint pattern differs in identical twins.

Fingerprints are formed during intrauterine life due to friction ridges. These ridges are created by pressure on the fingers from touching the surroundings. Hence, it is unique to every individual.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and left-sided limb weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and her CT appears normal. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient. Intravenous thrombolysis(alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Aspirin + clopidogrel(Option B) is used in secondary prevention of stroke and also to prevent stroke following TIA.

Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) refer to episodes of stroke symptoms that have a brief duration, the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 hr. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA, the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms.

The risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is approximately 10-15% in the first three months, majorly in the first two days. A reliable estimation of this risk can be obtained using the ABCD2 score. 

Other options: 

Option A: If CT is normal it only rules out hemorrhagic stroke and changes of ischemic stroke usually take time to appear on NCCT.

Option D: BP control is done when BP exceeds 220/120 mmHg, if there is malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg and thrombolytic therapy is anticipated. 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: The image given below shows an eyeball with a refractive error. All the following fundal changes can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. Hence, the refractive error is myopia. All the fundal changes mentioned above can be seen in myopia, except cattle track appearance.

Cattle truck appearance is seen in branch retinal artery occlusion (not myopia).

Pathological/degenerative myopia is characterized by progressive anteroposterior elongation of the scleral envelope associated with secondary ocular changes due to mechanical stretching of the involved tissues.

Clinically patients present with defective vision, floating black opacities (muscae volitantes), and difficulty with night vision. Examination of the fundus reveals the following changes:

  • Optic disc:
    • Temporal myopic crescent
  • Retina and choroid:
    • Lacquer cracks are fine irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole, due to ruptures in the Bruch membrane.
    • Subretinal coin hemorrhages develop from lacquer cracks.
    • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion at the macula which develops after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed.
    • A pale tessellated (tigroid) appearance of the fundus is seen due to diffuse attenuation of the RPE with large choroidal vessels.
    • Lattice degeneration
  • Vitreous: Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) appears as Weiss' reflex.
  • Posterior staphyloma.

The image given below shows fundal changes seen in pathological myopia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

Related Pearl: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

  • Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.
  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a PHC where you diagnose a patient with TB. Within how many days do you have to report it to the District Health Officer?
questions.solution:
The guidelines for TB notification under the RNTCP is within 30 days (a month) of receiving a new case. The notification must be done to the District Health Officer or the Chief Medical Officer of a District Hospital by the practitioner who diagnosed it.

Note: RNTCP has now been renamed to National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.solution:
The image shows hinge fracture/ motorcyclists fracture. Here, the base of the skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of the other like a hinge.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Menopause is defined as cessation of menses for a period of _____.
questions.solution: Menopause is defined as cessation of ovarian function for 12 months resulting in permanent amenorrhoea. It is a retrospective diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid).

Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most common symptom is menorrhagia.

Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations:

Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most common type of uterine fibroids.

Other options:

Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women.

The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text:
What is the defective DNA repair mechanism in a patient with SCID?

(SCID - severe combined immunodeficiency)
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). 

NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, enhancing T and B cell diversity. Thus, NHEJ deficiency leads to combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. 

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterised by defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R. Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria. 

X-linked SCID is the most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys. The genetic defect is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. In these patients, the thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells, resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive SCID is commonly caused by a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme. In these patients, the thymus contains remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given histological image shows ferruginous bodies. When these bodies are present in the case of asbestosis, they are called as asbestos bodies.

They are inorganic particulates like asbestos coated with iron-protein complexes.

Other options:

  • Psammoma bodies are seen commonly in papillary thyroid carcinoma and papillary renal cell carcinoma.
  • Alkapton bodies are seen in alkaptonuria.
  • Warthin-Finkeldey bodies are seen in Measles
