questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The appropriate management of a 45-year-old with a positive pap smear and post-coital bleeding is a colposcopy-directed biopsy.

A per speculum examination must be done whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding in order to evaluate for carcinoma of the cervix. If growth is visible, a punch biopsy should be done, and else if no growth is visible, then a pap smear is done. A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and pap co-test every 5 years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If a pap smear is suspicious, then screening is continued till 75 years. HIV+ve women should have annual checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.

Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A 37-year-old presented with fever. On examination,​ he had enlarged and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral blood smear showed lymphocytosis. Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done and it showed large cells mixed with lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, EBV LMP1, MUM1, CD 79a. Background cells were positive for CD3. The cells are negative for CD15. Your most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a likely diagnosis of EBV positive DLBCL, NOS (Epstein Barr virus-positive Diffuse Large B cell Lymphoma, Not otherwise specified).

The given slide shows sheets of large lymphoid cells with irregular vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli typical of DLBCL.

Approach to the question:

  • In the given case, Monospot test negative rules out Infectious Mononucleosis and the identification of Reed-Sternberg cell and their variant is essential for the diagnosis of Hodgkin Lymphoma, which can also be ruled out.
  • EBV-positive mucocutaneous ulcer is a localized lymphoproliferative disorder in immunocompromised patients. It is a self-limiting ulcer which reverts on treatment in Immunocompromised people. Histologically characterized by atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology. Hence, this is also ruled out.
  • EBV positive DLBL(Diffuse Large B cell Lymphoma) occurs in patients more than 50 years of age and without a previous history of lymphoma. DLBCL typically presents as a rapidly enlarging mass at a nodal or extranodal site.
  • Immunohistochemical studies indicate that EBV+ DLBCL, NOS is molecularly heterogeneous with a prominent background of T lymphocytes. The cells are positive for CD 20, CD 79a, IRF4/MUM1. EBV LMP-1(Latent membrane protein-1) is positive in about 2/3rdof cases, while EBNA-2 (Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen) is positive in the remaining 1/3rd of cases. It is negative for CD10 and BCL6.

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.

Thyroid hormones enter the nucleus and bind to thyroid hormone receptors. The hormone-receptor complex in the nucleus binds to DNA via zinc fingers. This increases the expression of a variety of different genes that code for proteins regulating cell function.  Although thyroxine is an AA derivative, there are transporters to move it into the cell, hence they are intracellular receptors acting on the nucleus.

Epinephrine, glucagon, and insulin bind to cell surface receptors.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was referred to the medicine OPD for the evaluation of a sudden syncopal attack that occurred while she was waiting for a bus. History revealed that she had felt hot and clammy before she lost consciousness. After some time she regained consciousness and was fully oriented. There were no similar episodes in the past. On examination, there are no abnormal physical findings. No orthostatic symptoms or signs were noted. Peripheral pulse and neurological examination were normal. No significant family history noted. ECG was normal.  What is your advice?

choices.text: Prescribe β blocker to prevent future episodes of syncope

questions.solution:
Reassure the patient. As part of initial evaluation, resting ECG is recommended for all patients. No further testing is required for patients with a normal initial evaluation, including unremarkable history and normal physical examination, absence of cardiac disease or any other significant comorbidities and a normal baseline ECG.

Other options:

Tilt-table testing is not required unless the vasovagal syncope is suspected where the diagnosis is unclear after initial evaluation, or if syncope is recurrent. In the above patient, this was her first syncopal attack, and her general physical examination findings were all normal.

Increased salt intake and volume replacement are unnecessary unless symptoms are recurrent.

Use of β-blocker therapy in most patients with neurocardiogenic syncope is not associated with a decrease in symptoms and is not routinely recommended, even for patients with recurrent episodes.

questions.text: Histology under KOH preparation showed the following bodies. This is seen in case of _________
questions.solution:
The image shows medlar bodies which are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Histologically on potassium hydroxide preparation, the lesions show the presence of the fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies/ medlar bodies/ copper penny bodies. These structures multiply by septation, and they induce a purulent and granulomatous inflammatory reaction in tissue.

Chromoblastomycosis is the most common form of chromomycosis, which is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi.

The M/C fungi responsible are species of the genera Fonsecaea (Fonsecaea pedrosoi or Fonsecaea compacta).

questions.text: Sweet syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Sweet syndrome is also known as acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis as it demonstrates intense dermal neutrophilic infiltrates with little evidence of primary vasculitis.

It presents with non-ulcerative lesions which have the following characteristics:

  • Tender
  • Plaques or nodules
  • Red/plum-colored (erythematous)
  • Heals with little scarring
  • On trunk, head, and limbs
  • Associated with:
    • High fever
    • Neutrophilic polymorphonuclear leukocytosis
    • Elevated ESR
  • Associated systemic diseases/Malignancy:
    • AML
    • Myeloma
    • Adenocarcinoma

Treatment of choice is corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Bell's palsy?

choices.text: MRI shows enhancement of geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
Maximal weakness occurs within 48 hours as a rule in Bells' palsy.

Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion of the facial nerve.

Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy:

  • Pain behind the ear (may precede paralysis and last for 1-2 days)
  • Bell's phenomenon
  • Asymmetrical face
  • Hyperacusis (due to stapedial paralysis)
  • Loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani).

MRI may reveal swelling and uniform enhancement of the geniculate ganglion and facial nerve.

Approximately 80% of patients recover within a few weeks or months. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favorable prognostic sign. Recurrence may be seen in some cases.

questions.text: All are true about Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score except ______

choices.text: Minimum score is 6 and maximum is 40
Prothrombin time is a component of MELD score
Conjugated bilirubin is a component of MELD score

questions.solution:
Total bilirubin is a component of MELD score not conjugated bilirubin.

 

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: Device shown in the image is used for which purpose?
questions.solution:
The image shows a leukoreduction filter which is used for filtering out donor WBCs. This helps in reducing the incidence of transfusion-related reactions by removing WBC microaggregates. The optimum time for performing leukoreduction is before the storage of blood.

Potential benefits include reduced risk of: 

  • Sensitization to HLA antigens (important for transplant patients & preventing platelet refractoriness)
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR)
  • CMV transmission

Note: CMV also has an affinity for monocytes and macrophages (types of WBCs). Reduction in WBCs is the cause for the decrease in CMV transmission (accidental benefit), and thus, the main purpose of a leukoreduction filter is not the prevention of CMV transmission (options A and C).

Possible reduced risk of:

  • Transfusion-associated graft versus host disease (TA- GVHD) 
  • Transfusion-related immuno-modulatory (TRIM) effects
  • Transmitting variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease

Other Methods of Leucodepletion are:

  • Specific leucodepletion filters (Most Efficient)
  • Washing
  • Freezing
  • Buffy coat removal
  • Micro-aggregate filtration
  • Low leucocyte apheresis devices

 

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: A construction worker got entrapped in a collapsed building. He sustained severe injury over his legs. Which of the following feature is unlikely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of crush syndrome. In this condition hyperkalemia is seen, not hypokalemia. 

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period. For e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalaemia and hypocalcaemia. The procoagulants escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Management of crush syndrome:

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis
  • Aggressive management of the open wound

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products?
questions.solution:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by papain.

Cleavage of the antibody molecule with pepsin generates one large fragment called F(ab´)2 and a digested Fc fragment.

The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by pepsin.

questions.text: Which of the following is best method to survey the injection practices of health workers?

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.solution:
Direct observation with a structured checklist is the best method to survey the injection practices of health workers.

Checklist of practices for assessment or evaluation include:-

  • In order not to harm the patient, each procedure should be administered with a new sterile single-use device, using the right medication, vaccine or fluid for infusion.
  • In order not to expose the provider to any avoidable risk, in general, any needles used during a procedure should be placed in a puncture-proof closed container immediately after use without recapping. In addition, providers of these procedures should be fully vaccinated against Hepatitis-B.
  •  In order that any waste produced during the performance of a procedure does not become a hazard for other people, used sharps waste and infectious non-sharps waste should be safely managed.

World Patient Safety Day is observed every year on September 17th. The theme for the 2020 campaign is "Safe health workers, Safe patients" which focuses on the interrelationship between health worker safety and patient safety. It emphasizes the need for a safe working environment for health workers as a prerequisite for ensuring patient safety.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles form the Passavant’s ridge?
questions.solution:
Passavant’s ridge is a mucosal ridge raised by the fibers of the palatopharyngeus. 

It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus. Soft palate, during its contraction makes firm contact with the ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during deglutition or speech.

questions.text: A 3 week old patient presenting with vomiting and failure to thrive is found to have pyloric stenosis. What should be the next step of management?

choices.text: Its emergency so do pyloromyotomy immediately

questions.solution:
Correction of electrolyte disturbances is the next step of management.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a medical emergency not a surgical emergency. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet, leading to nonbilious, projectile emesis, loss of hydrochloric acid with the onset of hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and dehydration. Immediate treatment requires correction of fluid loss and electrolytes imbalance.

  • An initial fluid bolus( 20mL/kg) of crystalloids should be infused immediately if infant is dehydrated.
  • Infants should receive 1.5 -2 times maintenance iv fluids: 150 - 180 ml/Kg/day of 0.9% saline with 0.15% Kcl in 5% glucose.
  • Definitive treatment  : Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:
questions.solution:
Anaphylactoid reactions are those reactions that are similar to the anaphylactic reactions but are not IgE mediated. These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators.

Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

In 2014, World Allergy Organisation has introduced two new terms:

  • Immunologic anaphylaxis - It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/ complement-mediated reactions.
  • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis (previously called anaphylactoid reaction) - It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: The incidence of a disease is 4 per 1000 of the population with an average duration of 2 years.  What is the prevalence?
questions.solution:
The prevelance in the given situation is 8/1000 population.

Prevalence is given by the formula :

Prevalance = Incidence x Mean Duration

Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 population

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Image of insulin regimen with different preparations of insulin is given below. The yellow curve in the image indicates
questions.solution:
The yellow curve in the image has a duration of action of around 11- 12 hours. Therefore, it indicates NPH insulin.

The image shows an insulin regimen consisting of a twice-daily injection of NPH insulin (yellow line) providing basal insulin coverage and regular insulin (blue dashed line) or an insulin analog (glulisine, apart, and lispro in red) providing mealtime insulin coverage.

Duration of NPH insulin is around 10-16 hours, insulin degludec is 24-42 hours, regular insulin is 4-6 hours and insulin glulisine is around 3-4 hours.

Other commonly used insulin regimens are shown in the following image. The letter B indicates breakfast, L indicates lunch, S indicates supper and HS indicates bedtime.

The above image shows multiple-component insulin regimen consisting of long-acting insulin (degludec, determir, or glargine), which are denoted by green color to provide basal insulin coverage and three shots of short-acting insulin (glulisine, lispro, or insulin aspart), indicated in red color, to provide glycemic coverage for each meal.

The above image shows the insulin level attained following subcutaneous insulin (short-acting insulin analogue) by an insulin pump programmed to deliver different basal rates. At each meal, an insulin bolus is delivered.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5 mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with symptomatic heart failure and K+ levels of 5.5 mg%. She requires a diuretic for symptom control. Furosemide can be given safely as it causes hypokalemia.

Other options:

Option A: Digoxin is not used as a first-line drug in the management of symptomatic heart failure.

Options B and C: Spironolactone (K+ sparing diuretic) and enalapril (ACE inhibitor) can cause hyperkalemia.  

The first step in managing acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) is addressing the factors that caused the decompensation. They include nonadherence to medications, dietary indiscretion, medication use that exacerbates heart failure, coronary ischemia, arrhythmias, valvular heart disease, infection, and pulmonary thromboembolism.

Volume management is crucial in ADHF. Intravenous loop diuretics are used to relieve congestion. The effectiveness of diuretic therapy can be assessed by changes in weight, improvement in symptoms, and clinical examination findings. Natriuretic peptide levels can also help assess the adequacy of therapy and predict risk.

Cardiorenal syndrome, characterized by the interplay between heart and kidney dysfunction, is a common complication of ADHF. Diuretic therapy should be carefully managed to avoid worsening renal function in patients with elevated right-sided filling pressures. In cases of severe low cardiac output, inotropic therapy or mechanical circulatory support may be necessary to preserve or improve renal function temporarily.

Vasodilators like nitroglycerin, sodium nitroprusside, and nesiritide (recombinant BNP) are used to reduce filling pressures and systemic vascular resistance. 

Inotropic therapy with drugs like dopamine and milrinone is used to increase myocardial contractility and improve cardiac output in patients with low-output ADHF. Dopamine has dose-dependent effects on different receptors, while milrinone is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Sodium nitroprusside

 Decrease preload and afterload
Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP
 
Intravenous positive inotropes

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Norepinephrine

 β1 receptor-mediated stimulation of cardiac output

Enoximone

Milrinone

 PDE 3/4 inhibitors

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

 Loop diuretics- used for symptomatic treatment of severe heart failure and acute decompensation.
Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses
ACE inhibitors Used as first-line therapy
ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity

questions.text: A patient of hemophilia received multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities can be seen in a patient?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the metabolic abnormality seen in a patient who has received multiple blood transfusions is metabolic alkalosis.

This is because the excess sodium citrate (anticoagulant) in the transfused blood gets converted to bicarbonate leading to metabolic alkalosis. Each mmol of citrate generates 3 mEq of bicarbonate (a total of 23 mEq of bicarbonate due to each unit of blood).

Metabolic acidosis can also be seen in multiple blood transfusions as citrate is acidic, but metabolic alkalosis is more common.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: What is the next line of management in a patient diagnosed with succinylcholine apnoea?
questions.solution:
The mainstay in the treatment of succinylcholine apnea due to atypical pseudocholinesterase is to continue mechanical ventilation until muscle function returns to normal by clinical signs.

Option B: Administration of neostigmine is controversial as the effects may be transient, possibly followed by an intensified neuromuscular blockade.

Option C: Fresh frozen plasma can augment the patient's endogenous plasma pseudocholinesterase activity but is not recommended because of the risk of iatrogenic viral infections.

Note: If human plasma cholinesterase is available, it can be given to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: A 53 year old man is found to have stage 2 hypertension without any co morbidities. Which drug will you start?
questions.solution:
Chlorthalidone is one of the first choice drugs in the treatment of hypertension without any comorbidities.
 
First-choice drugs used in the treatment of hypertension in patients without any comorbidities include:
  • Thiazide diuretics: Chlorthalidone is usually preferred to hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred.
  • ACE inhibitors: Captopril is preferred for the initiation of therapy. Enalapril and ramipril twice daily may also be used.
In the presence of any associated conditions or comorbidities, the first choice drugs for the treatment of hypertension would be as follows:
 
Conditions associated with hypertension
First choice drugs for hypertension
Diabetes
Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
Inhibitors of renin-angiotensin system.
Angina
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Heart failure
ACE inhibitors and alpha+beta blockers such as carvedilol
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
α1 Blockers
Pregnancy
Labetalol
Atrial fibrillation
Diltiazem and verapamil

questions.text: An X-ray done for a child with a history of a fall showed the following finding. Which of the following complications is least likely to be seen in this child?

choices.text: Inability to do OK sign with fingers

questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Malunion leading to cubitus varus (gunstock deformity) is the most common complication following this fracture. Cubitus valgus is a very rare complication.

Cubitus varus is characterized by posterior displacement, horizontal rotation, and coronal tilt of the distal fragment. Correction methods include:

  • Lateral closed-wedge osteotomy
  • Medial open-wedge osteotomy (King's osteotomy)

The images below shows gunstock deformity.

Complications of supracondylar fracture of the humerus can occur early or late.

Early complications :

  • Vascular injury - to the brachial artery resulting in
    • Volkmann's ischemia
    • Compartment syndrome
    • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture
  • Nerve injury - to the anterior interosseus nerve> median >radial >ulnar nerve

Late complications :

  • Gunstock deformity
  • Elbow stiffness
  • Heterotopic ossification (myositis ossificans)

Patients with anterior interosseous nerve injury are unable to perform the OK sign. This is due to weak flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus muscles. The fingers get pinched, and instead of the tips, the volar surfaces of the thumb and index finger make contact.

questions.text: The grade of the given urological condition and the surgical treatment option with the best outcome for this condition depicted in the image is

choices.text: Grade 4, Nephrectomy of the Damaged Kidney to Prevent Recurrent UTI

questions.solution:
The image shows a Grade V vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). The surgical treatment for this is ureteric reimplantation & it has 95-97% cure rates. Here, the ureter is reimplanted in a different site in the bladder from the normal anatomic site.

As VUR is autosomal dominant, USG screening is done is other siblings to rule out the disease.

However, micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) remains the investigation of choice.

Scars can be ruled out using DMSA Renal Scintigraphy.

VUR is the most common cause of renal scarring, and hence, scarring is considered one of the indications of VUR.

The other surgical modalities mentioned in the options have no role in isolated Vesicoureteric Reflux.

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated tortuous ureter
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

questions.text: Dohlman’s  procedure is  for:
questions.solution:
Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker’s diverticulum.

It is a transoral endoscopic approach, that ablates the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Other options:

Option A: Meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is treated by surgical resection.

Option C: Bochadlek’s hernia is a congenital posterolateral defect on the left side of the diaphragm due to defective embryological development.

Option D: Menetrier’s disease is a premalignant condition with gross hypertrophy of gastric mucosal folds and is treated with gastrectomy. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: As per the Medicare Service Persons and Damage to Property in Medicare Service  Institutions Act, violence against a registered medical practitioner is considered as:
questions.solution:
As per the Medicare Service Persons and Damage to Property in Medicare Service Institutions (Prevention of Violence and Damage or Loss to Property) Act, violence against a registered medical practitioner is considered a cognizable and non-bailable offense.  

As per this law, enacted by many Indian states, violence against registered medical practitioners, registered nurses, medical and nursing students, and paramedical and other auxiliary workers carries a penalty of imprisonment and fine.  

Violence means activities of causing any harm, injury, or endangering the life or intimidation, obstruction, or hindrance to any medicare service person while discharging their duty in the medicare service institution or causing damage or loss to the property.

The period of imprisonment may extend from 3 to 10 years in certain states.

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother presented to the clinic with fever and breast pain for the past 2 days. The affected breast appears as shown in the image below. There is extreme tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most common source for the organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of lactational mastitis. The most common source of infection is from the infant's nasopharynx.

Lactational mastitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx. The organism enters the breast tissue through cracked nipples and multiplies in the stagnant breast milk. Patients present with fever with a firm, red, tender, and swollen quadrant of the unilateral breast.

Painful breasts must be managed by the use of analgesics. Breastfeeding should be continued if the pain is less severe. Antibiotics like flucloxacillin, co-amoxiclav are used to treat the infection. If the patient develops an abscess, then the abscess has to be drained by aspiration or incision.

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation due to ascending infection or infection due to milk stasis  Occurs as a complication of mastitis, with pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness, erythema Point tenderness, erythema, induration of skin (if chronic) lymphadenopathy, fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics, antibiotics Analgesics, aspiration of pus, antibiotics

questions.text: All the following nerves can cause winging of the scapula if injured, except:
questions.solution:
The thoracodorsal nerve does not cause winging of the scapula. It supplies latissimus dorsi muscle and if injured, the patient will not be able to extend, adduct, or medially rotate the arm.

Nerves causing winging of scapula:

Nerves Muscles Type of winging
Spinal accessory nerve

Trapezius and sternocleidomastoid

 The superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent (lateral winging)
Long thoracic nerve

Serratus anterior

 The scapula is pulled upwards and towards the spine by the unopposed action of the trapezius (medial winging)
Dorsal scapular nerve Levator scapulae, rhomboid major, and rhomboid minor Similar to serratus anterior but mild winging

questions.text: Suspicious deaths were occurring after receiving parcels via mail in the USA. The microscopy of the specimen collected showed the following appearance. The bioterrorism agent involved can also show ___________
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a bioterrorism agent with the gram stain showing a box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis (Category A bioterrorism agent). Bacillus anthracis can also show a medusa head appearance on microscopy.

Bacillus anthracis is a non-motile gram-positive bacillus that has a characteristic box car or a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining. On the agar plate, they form irregular round colonies that are raised, dull, greyish-white colonies giving a frosted glass appearance as given in the image below.

Long interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling matted hair, are present on the edge of the colonies giving it a medusa-head appearance when seen on low-power microscopy.

M’Fadyean’s reaction is used to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule which is stained with polychrome methylene blue. It also shows an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab culture. On a solid media containing penicillin, the colonies give a string of pearls appearance as given in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: A fried egg appearance of colonies is seen in the case of Mycoplasma.

Option C: Draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies on blood agar is seen in the case of Streptococcus pneumonia, as given in the image below.

Option D: A fluorescent antibody-stained specimen of Yersinia pestis reveals rod-shaped bacteria with characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin or hairpin-like appearance.

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples

High priority agents

Easily disseminated

High mortality rate

Capacity to get disseminated

Social disruption

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Clostridium botulinum

Yersinia pestis

Variola major

Francisella tularensis

Ebola and other hemorrhagic fevers

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Category B

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant women came with a history of thyroid swelling. FNAC report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid and the nodule was “cold” on scan. Which of the following will not be a treatment option for her?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy plus lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Radioactive ablation of the thyroid is an absolute contraindication in pregnancy as it can cause fetal goiter and hypothyroidism. 

Radioactive ablation of the thyroid is done using the radioactive isotope of iodine (I-131), which has a half-life of 8 days. I-131 emits gamma rays (useful in imaging) and beta particles (useful in therapy). I-131 is concentrated within the thyroid follicles and emits radiation from within the tissue. The beta particles penetrate only 0.5-2 mm of the tissue. The thyroid follicular cells are affected from within and undergo pyknosis and necrosis followed by fibrosis without damage to neighboring tissues. 

Radioactive iodine is administered as the sodium salt of I-131 dissolved in water and taken orally.

Therapeutic uses of radioactive iodine:

  • Distant metastasis at diagnosis (papillary or follicular carcinoma)
  • Incomplete tumor resection 
  • Patients at high risk for mortality or recurrence 
  • Graves disease 
  • Toxic multinodular goitre 

The average therapeutic dose is 3-6 m curie, calculated based on previous tracer studies and thyroid size.

Contraindications: 

  • Pregnancy 
  • Lactation 
  • Young age (<25 years) 
  • Moderate to severe Graves ophthalmopathy 

Management of differentiated thyroid cancer in pregnancy: 

  • Thyroidectomy after delivery for patients with no evidence of advanced disease or no rapid progression and in the second trimester for patients with rapid progression or signs of advanced disease.
  • Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnancy and lactation. If it is needed after delivery, breastfeeding shall be stopped at least 6 weeks before ablative therapy and mothers should be advised against nursing.
  • Levothyroxine supplementation: as a suppressive treatment for those who decided to postpone surgery till the second trimester or after delivery, as a replacement therapy after thyroidectomy, and as a suppressive therapy for patients with residual disease.
  • Differentiated thyroid cancer not responding to radioactive iodine can be treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

Diagnostic radioiodine scan:  25–100 µ curie of I-131 is given; counting or scanning is done at intervals.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of women with fishy odor vaginal discharge is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV). The microscopic finding is vaginal epithelial cells with bacteria attached to their surface called clue cells, creating a poorly defined cellular border. They are the most reliable indicators of BV. 

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by a decrease in lactobacilli and an overgrowth of anaerobic bacterial species, including gardnerella, prevotella,mobiluncus, and bacteroides. Multiple or new sexual partners, having female partners, and engaging in oral sex are associated with a higher risk of BV. They may experience a foul-smelling (fishy odor) thin vaginal discharge. 

The clinical diagnosis of BV is based on the presence of three out of four Amsel criteria: elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), thin noninflammatory discharge, >20% clue cells, and a fishy odor (positive whiff test) after adding 10% potassium hydroxide to a vaginal sample. creating a poorly defined cellular border. 

BV is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes such as preterm birth, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and postpartum endometritis. It also increases susceptibility to sexually transmitted infections, including HIV.

The recommended treatment options in nonpregnant women include oral metronidazole, metronidazole gel, or clindamycin cream. Alternative options include oral secnidazole, tinidazole, or clindamycin. Partner treatment is not needed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a definitive criterion used to diagnose PID?
questions.solution:
A temperature of more than 38.3°C is an additional criterion and not a definitive criterion for the diagnosis of PID. 

CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID:

Definitive criteria:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
  • Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (Tubo-ovarian abscess)
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID

Minimum criteria:

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Additional criteria:

  • Oral temperature>38.3C
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria?
questions.solution:
Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria.

The drugs with clinically important gametocidal activity (against all species) are:

  • High activity:
    • Artemisinins
    • Primaquine
  • Low to moderate activity:
    • Chloroquine
    • Quinine
    • Atovaquone/proguanil
  • No activity:
    • Mefloquine
    • Pyrimethamine
    • Sulfadoxine
    • Tetracycline

questions.text: An AIDS patient on treatment with  AZT, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole, and cotrimoxazole, develops breast hypertrophy, central adiposity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and nephrolithiasis. Which of the following drugs could have caused these?
questions.solution:
Indinavir, a protease inhibitor, is the most likely cause for these adverse effects.

Patients being treated with protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir) develop a syndrome involving the derangement of lipid metabolism. This causes changes in body fat distribution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has also been reported. This is called HIV/HAART-associated lipodystrophy.

Indinavir can also precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient is maintained in a high state of hydration.

Indinavir binds to the site of HIV-1 protease activity and inhibits cleavage of viral gag-pol polyprotein precursors into individual functional proteins required for infectious HIV. This results in the formation of immature, non-infectious viral particles.

Option A: Azidothymidine or zidovudine, is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Chronic zidovudine administration has been associated with nail hyperpigmentation. 

Option C: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis. Its adverse effects include liver dysfunction and testosterone synthesis inhibition leading to gynecomastia. 

Option D: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It is one of the least toxic antiretroviral drugs. Neutropenia, headache, and nausea have been reported at higher-than-recommended doses.

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: The image of the eye of a 32-year-old woman having superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis is given below. Which of the following is commonly associated with it?
questions.solution:
Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis has a definite association with thyroid dysfunction. It affects one or both eyes of middle-aged women and about 65% of patients have abnormal thyroid function (usually hyperthyroidism).

It is a chronic disease of the superior limbus and the superior bulbar and the tarsal conjunctiva.

Clinical features:

  • Papillary hypertrophy of the superior tarsal plate, often having a diffuse velvety appearance.
  • Hyperemia of a radial band of the superior bulbar conjunctiva that stains with rose bengal.
  • Superior filamentary keratitis that develops in about one-third of cases.

Management:

  • Preservative-free lubricants
  • Topical acetylcysteine 10% to 20%, four times daily to break down filaments
  • Topical rebamipide

questions.text: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.solution:
Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property.

Nebivolol:

  • Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective β1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via β3 receptor agonism
  • Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension
  • It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
  • Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: A 7 year old child presents to the clinic with the following skin lesion. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
This "classic" bull's-eye rash is also called erythema migrans. This lesion is usually seen in individuals with Lyme’s disease.
In children with Lyme disease amoxicillin is the drug of choice.

Doxycycline is generally the drug of choice in Lyme’s disease except in pregnant, lactating women and children under 8 where amoxicillin is used.
Doxycycline is preferred because it has excellent CNS penetration and it can be used to treat anaplasmosis which can coexist with the Lyme’s disease.

Ceftriaxone is reserved for patients with late neurological findings.
Although Azithromycin can be used for treatment treating with amoxicillin gave superior results and shorter treatment time.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to you with fatigue & palpitations. She gives a history of 4 spontaneous abortions early during pregnancy & provides a lab report showing very high titers of anti- beta2 glycoprotein 1. On cardiac auscultation, you hear a pansystolic murmur.  Which of the following vegetations would you most likely find on Echocardiography?
questions.solution:
The vegetations depicted in "Image D", consistent with Libman Sacks Endocarditis are most likely to be seen in Echo.

The h/o repeated, early spontaneous abortions & lab report showing high titers of anti beta2 glycoprotein1 are strongly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS). With this background, the given presentation of fatigue, palpitations, and finding of the pan-systolic murmur (most likely of MR) should raise a strong suspicion for Libman sack’s endocarditis. It is characterized by very small vegetations, on either or both sides of the valve as given in "Image D".

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may occur alone (primary) or in association with other autoimmune diseases, mainly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (secondary).

Diagnosis:

  • The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia.
  • The presence of at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion is compatible with the diagnosis, in the absence of other thrombophilia causes.
  • Clinical criteria include:
    • Vascular thrombosis defined as one or more clinical episodes of arterial, venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ
    • Pregnancy morbidity, defined as:
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond the tenth week of gestation
      • One or more premature births of a morphologically normal neonate before the thirty-fourth week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before the tenth week of gestation

  • Laboratory criteria for APS include high titers of any 1 of the following three antiphospholipid antibodies on two occasions, 12 weeks apart 

    • Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - It is measured indirectly by
      • Diluted Russell's viper venom time assay (most specific) 
      • Kaolin coagulation time(KCT)
      • prolongation of aPTT
    • Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay (most sensitive)
    • Anti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay

questions.text: As an intern posted in the Labour Ward, you observe a newborn with typical Potter facies as shown below. Which of the following associations would you not expect in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic features consistent with potter Syndrome facies. It has male, not female predominance.

Features of Potter Syndrome are:

  • Bilateral Renal Agenesis leads to oligohydramnios, in turn causing pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Resultant characteristic Potter Facies -
    • Widely separated eyes with epicanthic fold
    • Small, low-set ears
    • Flat & broad nose
    • Receding Chin
  • Limb Anomalies
  • Wrinkled Skin

Interestingly, the cause of death is pulmonary insufficiency from pulmonary hypoplasia, not renal failure.

questions.text: “a” wave on JVP is for
questions.solution:
"a" wave in JVP represents atrial contraction.

Waves of JVP :

  • a- atrial systole pushing the blood to the ventricles.
  • c- isovolumetric contraction of ventricles causing the tricuspid valve to bulge.
  • x'- fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pull of valve leaflets.
  • v- venous filling which creates an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y- passive filling of ventricles by a passive flow of the blood from the right atrium.

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought in to the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An MRI  revealed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done and the image is given below. Which of the following test can be used for the diagnosis of the organism?
questions.solution:
The above image (showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasmosis bradyzoites encased in cysts with a cyst wall) and the case scenario suggest that the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep grey nuclei.

  • Acute lesions exhibit central necrosis, petechial hemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci.
  • Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by the gliotic brain.

Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma. IIF, IHA, and CFT (component fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. The dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine & leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Primary Prophylaxis:

  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL : Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX)
  • The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

Other options:

Option A: Casoni’s test is used for Hydatid cysts.

Option B: Bachman test is used for Trichinellosis.

Option D: Montenegro test is used for Leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in:
questions.solution:
Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in herpes simplex infection. 

The classic Cowdry type A (Lipshutz) inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HSV, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The  ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with absent P wave is suggestive of paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next best step in the management of a patient with unstable vitals (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) is synchronized cardioversion.

Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice in unstable PSVT patients, in which shocks are delivered with the defibrillator/monitor in synchronized mode with an initial energy level of 100J. Synchronization times the delivery so that it is given at the peak of the QRS complex.

If the shock occurs in the ST segment or the T wave (unsynchronized), it can precipitate a more serious arrhythmia such as ventricular fibrillation.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation

Used in unstable PSVT, atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, and ventricular tachycardia with a pulse

 Used in ventricular tachycardia without pulse and ventricular fibrillation.
Shock is delivered in sync with the R wave (in absolute refractory period) Shock is delivered at any time during the cardiac cycle.

Monophasic: 100-200 J

Biphasic: 50-100 J

Monophasic: 360 J

Biphasic:120-200 J

Other options:

Option A: In the absence of hemodynamic instability, a repeat dose of injection adenosine (maximum of 12mg) could be attempted.

Option B: IV Amiodarone is rarely used in the acute management of PSVT. Instead, it is used as an alternative to calcium channel blockers in chronic suppressive therapy.

Option D: Defibrillation is only done for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This image indicates the diagnostic features of Barrett’s esophagus.

The histological image above shows the transition between normal squamous epithelium and the mucin-filled glands, indicating intestinal-type metaplasia with plenty of goblet cells.

Barrett’s esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett’s Esophagus must be subjected to a regular surveillance endoscopy annually or with 2-year intervals, provided no dysplasias have been detected. The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian race.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male underwent tooth extraction for caries tooth. 3 days later he presents with a fever and swelling on the right side of his neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He also complains of difficulty in moving his jaw. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is found to be displaced medially. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, would be parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone)

Other options:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • Vincent’s angina (trench mouth) is an acute necrotizing infection of the oral cavity and the oropharynx.

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

  Prestyloid Poststyloid

Spasm of medial pterygoid muscle leading to trismus

The pharynx bulging behind the posterior pillar

Sympathetic chain injury leading to Horner’s syndrome

questions.text: A 22-year-old female undergoes emergency C section. 1 hour postoperatively, you notice blood loss from her genital tract. The amount of blood loss to consider it PPH (PostPartum Hemorrhage) will be
questions.solution:
1000 ml blood loss from genital tract is considered PPH after a C section.  

Loss of more than 500ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labor in vaginal delivery is considered as PPH.

Recent Update :

PPH is classically defined by the volume of blood loss. But this definition will soon become obsolete due to its unreliability as the bleeding may not be visible externally, or blood in collection devices may be mixed with the amniotic fluid.

In 2017, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists revised their definition of PPH to

  • Cumulative blood loss of ≥1000 mL or
  • Bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of the birth process (regardless of the route of delivery )

questions.text: Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.solution:
A breast tumor of size > 5 cm (not 4 cm) is classified as locally advanced breast carcinoma (LABC). 

Invasive breast carcinoma is of 3 types:

  1. Early breast carcinoma (EBC) - TNM combination of T1 to T2, N0 to N1, and M0
  2. Locally advanced breast carcinoma (LABC) - T4N0M0, T3N1M0, TanyN2-3M0
  3. Advanced breast carcinoma (ABC) - TanyNanyM1

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes:

  1. Breast tumors more than 5 cm in diameter 
  2. Cancers that involve the skin or the underlying muscles of the chest (T4 of TNM staging)
  3. Cancers that involve multiple local lymph nodes (axillary or sub clavicular) 
  4. Inflammatory breast cancer - a rapidly growing type of cancer that makes the breast appear red and swollen 

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

No evidence of primary tumor

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b
