Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with limb in the position shown in the image. He is crying and refuses to let anyone touch his hand. On probing, the father says he tried to lift him by holding his forearm after their mock-up baseball match. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows Nursemaid's Elbow/ Pulled Elbow.

The history of lifting by holding the forearm and the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow. The arm is held more or less immobile with the elbow fully extended and the forearm pronated; any attempt to supinate the forearm is resisted. 

 

Pulled elbow: Dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament is a fairly common injury in children under the age of 6 years.

Management: Simple analgesia is provided and, while the child’s attention is diverted, the elbow is extended and pronated (the alternative technique of supination and flexion is more painful and less successful). The radial head is relocated with a snap.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

questions.text: The image shows a male child with an anterior abdominal wall that is flabby and thin.   The bowel contours appear obvious on inspection and on examination the scrotum is empty. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Prune Belly Syndrome.

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have anti-HBc antibody even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG anti-HBc is found in chronic states. 

The HBsAg antigen is present in chronic hepatitis B, while the antibody anti-HBs is not.

questions.text: Nuchal translucency, to screen aneuploidy is done at which week?
questions.solution:
• Nuchal translucency evaluation is done in between 11-14weeks for the aneuploidy screening
  • It is done in sagittal plane
  • When the nuchal translucency is increased the risk for fetal aneuploidy and various fetal anomalies like heart defects is significantly increased.

questions.text: A 20 year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed normal uterus but gonads weren’t detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 46 XY individual with female internal & external genitalia and poorly developed breasts, presenting with primary amenorrhea points towards the diagnosis of sweyer’s syndrome.

Turner syndrome (option B) is a disorder of 45 XO individuals with short stature. The gonads in these individuals are streak ovaries.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (option A) is a disorder of 46 XY individuals with complete insensitivity to testosterone. These individuals have female external genitalia with an absent uterus. Secondary sexual characteristics like the development of breasts are adequate. However,pubic and axillary hairs are scanty.

True hermaphrodite (option C) can be a 46 XX or 46 XY individual with both ovaries and testis. These individuals have both male and female internal genitalia with ambiguous external genitalia.

Sweyer’s syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphroditism where there is an inactivation of the SRY gene that leads to formation of dysgenetic testis.

Thus,in the absence of hormones; AMH & testosterone the mullerian duct grows and the wolffian duct regresses forming female internal genitalia such as uterus (infantile type).

These patients also lack the DHT hormone and hence present with poorly developed breasts ( tanner staging 1 or 2), scanty pubic,axillary hair and female external genitalia. These individuals are of normal stature with increased LH & FSH.

Management includes gonadectomy as soon as diagnosed and estrogen + progesterone for breast development.

AMH: Anti mullerian hormone
DHT: dihydro testosterone

questions.text:
An adolescent girl is brought to OPD with a history of delayed menses. On examination, you note the following developmental changes. What is the Tanner staging?
  • The breast is elevated like a small mound
  • Pubic hair is long, slightly curved. Pigmented hair is present sparsely over the labia
questions.solution:
The breast elevated as a small mound and pigmented, slightly curved pubic hair is seen in Tanner stage 2.

Tanner staging Breast changes  Pubic hair changes 
Stage 1

B1 - Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage, only the papilla is elevated.

 P1 - No pubic hair
Stage 2

B2 - Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound.

 P2 - The appearance of pigmented hair sparsely over the labia, either long or slightly curved.
Stage 3

B3 - There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours.

 P3 - Darker, coarser and curly hair
Stage 4

B4 - Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to formation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast.

 P4 - Preadult stage cover short inverted triangular distribution.
Stage 5

B5 - Formation of the mature adult breast.

 P5 - Adult inverted triangular distributuion.

questions.text: The blood vessels to the skin are not derived from:
questions.solution:
The blood vessels to the skin are not derived from epidermal arterial plexus. 


In fact, the epidermis derives its nutrition via diffusion from the capillaries present in the dermal papillae as blood vessels do not penetrate the epidermis. 

The arterial plexuses supplying the skin from superficial to deep are:

  • Rete subpapillare or papillary plexus - located below the level of dermal papillae
  • Rete cutaneum or reticular plexus - located just below the dermis
  • Plexus over the deep fascia


Interestingly, cutaneous blood supply maintains body temperature by regulating the blood flow through the capillary bed through the numerous arteriovenous anastomosis.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. 

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.

Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision.

The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy:

Reinke's edema (Option A) is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The laryngoscopic image below shows Reinke's edema:

questions.text: Observe the following curves, which of the following is a true statement about sensitivity and specificity when the curve changes from green to pink?
questions.solution:
Both sensitivity and specificity are higher in the test represented in pink (Test B) compared to the test represented in green (Test A).

Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive. It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present.

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 – false-negative rate.

Specificity is the proportion of all people without the disease who test negative. It is the probability of the test being negative when the disease is absent.

Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 – false-positive rate.

Test B has an increased number of true positives and true negatives and decreased number of false positives and negatives, compared to Test A. 

Hence leading to increased sensitivity and specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?
questions.solution:
The β-1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis. This condition is usually diagnosed based on clinical features and culture.

The β-1-3 glucan assay detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG), an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi. It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta-D-glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

Fungi that do not contain BDG in their cell walls include Cryptococcus neoformans, zygomycetes like rhizopus and mucor and Blastomyces dermatitidis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes, which do not contain (1-3)-β-d-glucan, and hence, the β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used for its diagnosis.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following:
questions.solution:
Restriction endonucleases can act on AAGCTT. 

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence. A palindromic sequence is a sequence that reads the same backward and forward. An example is listed below.

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'
3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

Restriction endonucleases enzymes are routinely used for DNA modification in laboratories, and they are a vital tool in molecular cloning.

questions.text: True statement about teduglutide is :

choices.text: It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer

questions.solution:
Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analogue.

It has been recently approved for the treatment of short bowel syndrome. Teduglutide binds to enteric neurons and endocrine cells, stimulating the release of a number of hormones such as insulin-like growth factor, this stimulates mucosal epithelial growth and enhances fluid absorption.

The drug has a t1/2 of 1–2 hours and is administered subcutaneously once daily. It can potentially cause bowel cancer, therefore it is not recommended for patients with active malignancies.

Note: GLP-1 analogs are used for the treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses have the hematology findings given below?
questions.solution:
The findings present in the above hematology slide are basophilic stippling  (punctate basophilia) with Cabot’s ring . They are features seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism).

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign

Other Options:

  • Minamata disease: Chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.
  • Chronic iron toxicity: In severe cases, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).
  • Arsenic poisoning: Can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: The numerator of perinatal mortality rate includes ___________

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.solution:
Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g is included in the numerator of perinatal mortality rate .

Perinatal mortality rate is described as late foetal and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000 grams at birth expressed as a ratio per 1000 live births weighing over 1000 gram at birth.

questions.text: The loading dose of MgSO4 in pre-eclampsia is?

choices.text: 4 ml Mgso4 (50% w/v) in 16 ml NS
8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS
12 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 8 ml NS

questions.solution:
The loading dose of MgSO4 is 8ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12ml NS. For loading dose IV infusion of 4g of 20% solution is needed. 

One 2mL vial has 1g MgSO4. Therefore, to make a 20% solution containing 4g of MgSO4, we would need to take 8 mL of 50% magnesium sulfate, and dilute it with 12 mL NS. Therefore the final 20mL solution (8+12) would have 4g of MgSO4, making it a 20% solution.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.  

MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia:

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute

followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM

(5 gm in each buttock)

5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4g IV slow over 15-20 minute

1-2 g/h IV infusion

Repeat injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only if the patellar reflex is present, respiratory rate is >12, and urine output is >30 mL/h. Magnesium sulfate is discontinued either 24 hours after delivery or 24 hours after the onset of convulsions (whichever is later).  

Loss of patellar reflex is the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity and occurs when the plasma magnesium level reaches 10 mEq/L. Elevated magnesium levels above 10 mEq/L weaken breathing, while 12 mEq/L or higher levels can lead to respiratory paralysis and arrest.

questions.text:
A young motorist sustained injuries in a road traffic accident. He was found to have fractures of multiple ribs anteriorly on both sides. Radial and femoral fractures were also present. On examination, the following was noted. What should be the immediate intervention?
  • Blood pressure- 80/60 mmHg
  • Heart rate- 140/min 
  • Respiratory rate- tachypnea
  • General state: agitated and restless
  • Jugular veins- distended
  • Respiratory system- B/L equal and adequate air entry
  • CVS- heart sounds barely audible. Femoral pulse weakly palpable. Distal pulses not felt

choices.text: Intercostal tube drainage on both sides

questions.solution:
The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and absence of heart sounds (Beck's triad) are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. An urgent pericardial tap needs to be done to relieve the tension on the heart chambers.

Although these features could be seen in tension pneumothorax as well, the presence of adequate bilateral air entry excludes this diagnosis.

Pericardiocentesis, also known as pericardial tap, can be performed with sub-xiphoid, parasternal, or apical approaches. The most common approach is a sub-xiphoid approach under echocardiographic guidance.

Option A: Rapid blood transfusion is needed in massive blood loss indicated by hypotension. Although this patient presents with hypotension, it is most likely a result of cardiac tamponade. Although blood transfusion is indicated, it will be effective only when the pericardial tap decompresses the pericardium.

Option C: Intercostal tube drainage is done in tension pneumothorax. The presence of adequate air entry bilaterally excludes this diagnosis.

Option D: The fixation of femur fracture and femoral artery is not a priority here. The inability to palpate pulses distal to the fracture could be a result of hypotension. This needs to be explored only if the patient fails to improve after the pericardial tap and blood transfusion.

questions.text: A new drug combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy for metastatic melanoma was prescribed by a radiotherapist. It prolongs the survival. Which of the following is true in this situation?

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.solution:
By the new drug combination, the survival of the patient has increased, hence incidence remains the same while prevalence increases.


Incidence: Number of new cases in a defined population in a specified period of time.
Prevalence: Number of old and new cases at a given point of time over a period of time.


Options A, B, D: The treatment only prolongs the disease, it has nothing to do with the occurrence of cases thereby nothing to do with incidence.

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhea is not a side effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are associated with dry mouth, and not sialorrhea.

System Side effects of SSRIs
Sexual Anorgasmia, Decreased libido
Gastrointestinal ( 5-HT3 receptor) Nausea, Diarrhea, Anorexia, Vomiting, Flatulence, and Dyspepsia
Nervous system Extremely vivid dreams or nightmares, Anxiety, Insomnia/sedation, Seizures, Emotional blunting
Anticholinergic Dry mouth, Constipation, Sedation
Cardiovascular Drug induced long QT syndrome
Hematological Easy bruising
Endocrine Mammoplasia, Galactorrhea

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is used for the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Methionine in the form of S-adenosyl methionine is used during the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Function of S-Adenosyl methionine:

1. Transmethylation reactions:

  • Norepinephrine to Epinephrine
  • Ethanolamine to Choline
  • Acetyl serotonin to Melatonin
  • Guanidinoacetate to Creatine

2.  DNA methylation

3.  Polyamine synthesis:

  • Cadaverine
  • Putrescine
  • Spermidine
  • Spermine

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
The minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines is 4 weeks.

This is because decreasing the interval between two doses may interfere with the antibody response and protection. Thus, live vaccines can either be given on the same day according to the schedule or 4 weeks apart.

Note: In Park 27th ed. the minimum interval between two live vaccines is given as 3 weeks. However, several other standard sources including CDC and UNDP suggested an interval of 4 weeks. When both are given in options, it is recommended to mark 4 weeks as the correct answer.

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

Related Pearl: Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome or Zellweger's syndrome is characterized by the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acid, abnormalities of synthesis of bile acids and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

It occurs in individuals with a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes. It is due to mutations in genes encoding certain proteins called peroxins (involved in various steps of peroxisome biogenesis) in all tissues. They accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. It causes severe neurological symptoms and most patients die in the first year of life.

Because of the poor outcome and high disease burden associated with Zellweger's syndorme, genetic counselling should be offered to parents of affected children. Carriers can be offered prenatal or preimplantation genetic diagnosis. Treatment is often supportive and symptom-based.

This question was asked in the recent AIIMS examination, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: While performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery,  the surgeon points out the Haller cells and their clinical significance. Which of the following is correct about these cells?

choices.text: They are related to the maxillary sinus
They are related to the optic nerve
They are related to the sphenoid sinus
They are related to the facial nerve

questions.solution:
Haller cells (infraorbital ethmoidal air cells) are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

The star-marked area in the given CT scan shows the Haller cell

questions.text: Prucalopride is a ______.
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a specific 5HT4 receptor agonist which increases bowel movements.

It is approved for use in women with chronic constipation where other laxatives have failed to provide relief.

questions.text:
A patient after thyroid surgery develops dyspnoea and stridor without any change in voice. Which of the following nerve is injured?

B/L - Bilateral

U/L - Unilateral

choices.text: U/L superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerves are injured in this case.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (B/L abductor paralysis), all the intrinsic muscles of larynx (except cricothyroid) are paralyzed. Vocal cords lie in median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. 

Classically, they present with airway compromise leading to dyspnoea and stridor. Voice quality is not affected as the paralysed cords assume their natural adducted position during phonation.

Other options

Option A: In bilateral superior laryngeal nerve paralysis, both the cricothyroid muscles are paralyzed with anaesthesia of upper larynx. Patients present with aspiration of food, cough, and choking fits with a weak and husky voice.

Option C: In unilateral superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis), all the muscles of larynx on one side are paralyzed. Vocal cord on the affected side will lie in cadaveric position. Glottic incompetence occurs as the healthy cord is unable to approximate the paralyzed cord.  They present with hoarseness of voice, aspiration of food, and ineffective cough.

Option D: In unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis, ipsilateral paralysis of all the intrinsic muscles (except cricothyroid) occurs. Vocal cord on the affected side lie in median or paramedian position. Patient maybe asymptomatic. Few may present with voice changes. However, aspiration and airway obstruction does not occur.

Nerve injured Clinical features
Unilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Few may have change in voice
  • No airway obstruction/ aspiration
Bilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Airway obstruction (dyspnea, stridor)
  • No change in voice
Unilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Weak voice with inability to raise the pitch
  • Anaesthesia of larynx on one side causing occasional aspiration
Bilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Aspiration of food (cough, choking)
  • Weak and husky voice
Unilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Aspiration of food
  • Ineffective cough
Bilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Aphonia
  • Aspiration of food
  • Inability to cough

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient came with complaints of non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of his head. Histological examination shows loss of hair with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting a young adult presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histology showing perifollicular hemorrhage is suggestive of trichotillomania (trichotillosis). 

Trichotillomania has to be differentiated from alopecia areata (Option A). Trichotillomania presents with incomplete hair loss within a patch with varying lengths of hair whereas alopecia areata shows smooth hairless patch with sparing of white hairs. Regular pitting of nails and exclamation mark hairs are seen in alopecia areata. When the diagnosis is uncertain, a scalp biopsy can be done. Perifollicular hemorrhage is characteristic of trichotillomania while peribulbar lymphocytic infiltrate is diagnostic of alopecia areata. 

Trichotillomania is classified under obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. It is characterized by recurrent body-focused repetitive behavior (hair pulling) and repeated attempts to decrease or stop the behavior. It is commonly seen in females. The hair loss is commonly seen over the vertex but can involve eyelashes, eyebrows, and beard.

The most effective treatment for trichotillosis is habit-reversal training (HRT).

Other options:

Option B: Telogen effluvium is diffuse hair loss resulting in non-scarring alopecia due to loss of telogen hairs due to fever, pregnancy, hypothyroidism or anemia.

Option C: Tinea infection shows patchy hair loss, resulting in non-scarring/scarring alopecia. Easy pluckability, broken hairs and wood's lamp positivity are features.

questions.text: Vaccine that requires strain change due to evolving organism is?
questions.solution:
Influenza vaccine requires periodic strain change due to antigenic change in the surface glycoprotein of the virus.

The change may be gradual (antigenic drift) or drastic (antigenic shift).

questions.text: Pilon fracture is:
questions.solution: Pilon fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal tibia. A pilon fracture is a descriptive term suggesting that the talus acts as a hammer, or pestle, that impacts and injures the tibial plafond.

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution: Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons’s fascia?

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

questions.solution:
Sibson’s fascia is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib, not the 2nd rib.

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane) serves as a plane of separation between the lower neck and the thorax and covers the apical part of the lung. It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra. It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles. The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

questions.text: Letulles technique is an autopsy technique characterised by ________

choices.text: Removal of organs one by one

questions.solution:
Letulle's technique is characterized by en masse removal of organs. It means thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one big organ block.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition.
questions.solution:
The image shows plexiform neurofibroma of the upper lid causing an S-shaped deformity of the upper lid and mechanical ptosis. This is seen particularly in neurofibromatosis type 1.

NF1 is caused by the autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. It is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS regulator. The disease is clinically diagnosed when any two of the following seven features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules (CALMs) - They are the hallmark of neurofibromatosis and are present in almost 100% of patients. They are present at birth but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life, and are scattered over the entire body. 
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules - They are iris hamartomas that are best identified by a slit-lamp examination. They are present in the majority of patients with NF1.
  • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones such as the tibia
  • Optic gliomas (most frequently observed CNS tumor in NF1)
  • A first-degree relative with NF-1

questions.text: Lesion of the structure marked 'A' causes:

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger
Loss of sensation at the tip of radial tubercle
Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft

questions.solution:
The structure marked 'A' in the diagram is median nerve in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the median nerve causes loss of sensation of the nail of the index finger.

Median nerve cutaneous supply:

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

Contents of cubital fossa: (From medial to lateral) - “MBBR”

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery
  • Biceps brachii tendon
  • Radial nerve

questions.text: Deficiency in which of the following vitamins can lead to metaplastic transformation in the lung?
questions.solution: The deficiency of vitamin A (retinoic acid) induces squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium.

questions.text: A nurse sustained a needle stick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV-positive. Which of the following is incorrect?

choices.text: Washing hands with soap and water
Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.solution:
Triple therapy (tenofovir 300mg + lamivudine 300mg + dolutegravir 50mg) is recommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), not monotherapy. 

Steps to be undertaken after a needlestick injury are:

  • Wash the wound and skin with water and soap. Do not scrub and avoid antiseptics.
  • Assess exposed individual:
    • Check baseline viral markers
    • Monitor for acute seroconversion illness within 3-6 weeks after exposure
    • If testing is positive, refer to ART center 
  • Assess exposure source and determine the risk of transmission 
  • Counseling and support
  • Initiate PEP at the earliest - preferably < 2 hours and ideally < 72 hours
  • 28-day prescription with drug information
  • HIV test at 3 months after exposure

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir 

RAL - Raltegravir 

AZT - Zidovudine 

ABC - Abacavir 

 

 

 

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Code

HIV Source Code

          PEP Recommendation

1

 1

 Not required

1

 2

 Recommended

2

 1

 Recommended

2

 2

 Recommended

3

 1/2

 Recommended

2/3

Not known

Consider PEP if HIV prevalence is high in the given population

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is on metoprolol. If verapamil is added, there is a risk of:
questions.solution:
Metoprolol, when added with verapamil, leads to bradycardia with AV block.

Verapamil and β blockers have additive effect on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, and the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block.

These agents can also have additive effect on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

Indication

Initial treatment of choice 

Hypertension alone or hypertension with diabetes/ cerebrovascular disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with coronary artery disease

ACEi/ ARB + beta blocker/CCB (A+B or A+C)

or

beta-blocker + diuretic (B+D)

or 

CCB+ diuretic/ beta-blocker (C+B or C+D)

Hypertension with chronic kidney disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction

ACEI/ ARB + diuretic + beta-blocker (A+D+B)

Pregnancy

Labetalol, Nifedipine, methyldopa

ACEi – Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

ARB – Angiotensin II receptor blockers

CCB – Calcium Channel Blockers

questions.text: On clinical examination of a patient complaining of intense itching, you notice the presence of the hang glider sign. This is caused by which of the following organisms_____?
questions.solution:
The hang glider sign refers to the dark triangular biting apparatus of Sarcoptes scabiei seen at the end of the subcorneal tunnel.

  • Demodex folliculorum is a follicle mite.
  • Ixodidae ticks are hard ticks.
  • Cimex hemipterus is a tropical bed bug. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother?
questions.solution:
Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers and should be taken for 10-14 days.

Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus. It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Clinical features of mastitis include:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Purulent nipple discharge
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Positive fluctuation test

A culture from nipple discharge or test-needle aspiration of the cellulitic area is done to confirm the organism and its antibiotic sensitivity. An ultrasonogram of the involved breast is done to exclude abscess. They are treated with antibiotics and adequate breast support. Choice of antibiotics in lactational mastitis:

  1. Dicloxacillin 500 mg 4 times a day is to be started empirically.
  2. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
  3. If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus species then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given for at least 10 days.

questions.text: A 22 year old newly married women consults you because of painful coitus, with the pain located at the vaginal introitus. It is accompanied by painful involuntary contraction of the pelvic muscles. The pelvic examination appears to be normal. Of the following, which is the most common cause ?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vaginismus, defined as involuntary spasm of the pelvis muscles and vaginal outlet. It is usually psychogenic.

It should be differentiated with frigidity(lack of sexual desire) and dyspareunia(pain/discomfort associated with sexual activity).

Dyspareunia is frequently associated with pelvic pathology such as endometriosis, pelvic adhesions or ovarian neoplasms.

The pain of vaginismus may be psychogenic in origin or due to pelvic pathology such as adhesions, endometriosis, leiomyomas.

Treatment of vaginismus is primarily pyschotherapeutic, as organic vulvar or pelvic cause(such as atrophy, Bartholin's gland cyst or abscess) is very rare.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with an acute-onset neck spasm. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he had been started on haloperidol 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage, the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia. 

Acute dystonia usually presents within hours or days of starting treatment with antipsychotic drugs. There is a higher risk among patients between the ages of 10–19. It occurs due to acute dopamine receptor antagonism.  It presents with spasms of the head and neck muscles and the tongue. The severest form includes an oculogyric crisis with extraocular muscle involvement.

Treatment is with anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Other options:

Option A: Akathisia is an extrapyramidal syndrome characterized by a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements, and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use.

Option C: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: It usually occurs weeks to months after starting neuroleptic therapy. Clinical manifestations include fever, extreme muscle rigidity, stupor, dystonia, tachycardia, and unstable blood pressure. Treatment is with dantrolene or with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine. The antipsychotic drug responsible should be immediately stopped.

Option D: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by choreiform movements which are quick, repetitive, involuntary movements, along with slower twisting athetotic movements. It occurs months or years after initiation of the treatment and is more frequent in the elderly.

questions.text: A drug label suggests storage in a 'cool' place. What is the temperature at which this drug is to be stored?
questions.solution:
Storing at a cool place means to store at 8-15 degrees C.

Label instructions Temperature
Store frozen            -20o C
Keep cool   8-15o C
Store at room temperature  15-25o C

Examples for drugs to be stored under cool temperature include insulin, nicorandil.

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except:
questions.solution:
Babesia is an intracellular parasite of RBCs, not of the hepatocytes.

Its trophozoites invade the RBCs.

The liver is usually not affected as babesia lack an exoerythrocytic phase.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the ER after a skateboarding accident during which he had fallen with head hitting the ground first. He has a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a tissue paper. The investigation of choice for localizing the site is:
questions.solution:
HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea. History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient came with a history of hyponatremia. He was treated by a large volume of hypertonic fluids over 24 hours following which the patient developed quadriparesis. What is the most likely cause for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical history of sudden correction of hyponatremia leading to central pontine myelinolysis, a common complication associated with the treatment of hyponatremia.

Central pontine myelinolysis/ Osmotic demyelination syndrome is seen due to rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia (hyponatremia lasting for more than 48 hrs). It results in the efflux of organic osmolytes from brain cells, which reduces intracellular osmolality and osmotic gradient, and water entry. 

Rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) causes hypertonic stress in astrocytes within the brain causing demyelination without inflammation at the base of the pons, with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.

Clinically patients present one or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, diplopia, a “locked-in syndrome,” dysphagia, dysarthria with/without loss of consciousness. 

MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without paraplegia.

Prevention can be done by restoration of severe hyponatremia gradually i.e. by ≤10 mmol/L (10 mEq/L) within 24 h and ≤20 mmol/L (20 mEq/L) within 48 h.

The image shows the MRI finding of central pontine myelinolysis with axial fat saturated T2-Weighted MRI showing hyperintense signal in the central pons.

Note: Brain infarct or brain stem injury usually do not result in a quadriparesis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given virus?

choices.text: Incubation period is less than 24 hours
Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure
It is eliminated from semen within 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The above image is of the Ebola virus showing the bowl of spaghetti appearance. Patients with Ebola virus disease are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever; intense weakness; vomiting; diarrhea; rashes; and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

Related Pearl: Important Shapes of Some Viruses

VIRUS

SHAPE

Rabies virus

Bullet shaped

Pox virus

Brick shaped

Tobacco mosaic virus

Rod shaped

Ebola virus

Filamentous

Astro virus

Star shaped

Adenovirus

Space vehicle shaped

Rotavirus

Wheel shaped

questions.text: Acantholysis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Acantholysis is not seen in bullous pemphigoid as it is associated with subepidermal blistering.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.

Acantholysis is classified as:

Primary

Secondary
Rupture of the desmosome first, forming circular acantholytic cells Ballooning of the keratinocyte first, forming circular acantholytic cells (Tzank cell) 

Seen in: 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease

Seen in:

  • Herpes simplex infections (HSV-1 and 2)
  • Varicella-zoster infections (chickenpox, shingles)

The image below shows acantholysis (note the rounded and free-floating, detached keratinocytes).

questions.text: Which modification will lead to a change in the biological activity of the hormone given in the picture?
questions.solution:
The hormone shown in the above image is insulin. Among the given options, changes in 29-30 amino acids in the B chain cause the generation of short and long-acting insulins depending on the modification.
 
Structure:
 
The primary structure of insulin consists of 2 polypeptide chains: A-chain(21 Amino acids) and B-chain(30 amino acids).
 
It has two interchain disulfide bonds, 
  • Between 7th amino acid of A chain and 7th amino acid of B chain 
  • Between 20th amino acid of A chain and 19th amino acid of B chain
 
One intrachain disulfide bond is present between the 6th amino acid of A-chain and 11th amino acid in A-chain.
 
Modification:
Various short and long-acting insulin analogs have been developed by modifying these amino acid residues.
  • Insulin lispro: Proline at position 28 and lysine at position 29 in the B-chain are interchanged. 
  • Insulin Aspart: Proline at position 28 in the B-chain is replaced by aspartic acid. 
  • Insulin glulisine: Asparagine at position 3 and lysine at position 29 in the B-chain are replaced by lysine and glutamic acid.
  • Insulin glargine: Asparagine at position 21 in the A-chain is replaced by glycine and the B-chain contains two extra amino acids(two arginine residues) at positions 31 and 32. 
  • Insulin detemir: Threonine at position 30 of the B-chain is removed and a 14-carbon fatty acid chain is added to position 29 of the B-chain.

questions.text: Centor criteria/score is used for the diagnosis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Centor criteria are used to identify the likelihood of Group A Streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis.

They include the following:

  • Absence of cough (1 point)
  • Tonsillar exudate (1 point)
  • Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (1 point)
  • Fever (1 point)

A score of

  • 0-1 - GAS infection unlikely
  • 4 - likely

In adults, the positive predictive value of these criteria is around 40% if 3 criteria are met and about 50% if 4 criteria are met.

Mnemonic

C- Cough not present

E- Exudates

N- Nodes

T- Temperature

(OR)

Other diagnostic Methods

  • Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal rapid antigen detection test (preferred diagnostic method in emergency settings)
  • Throat culture (criterion standard for diagnosis of GAS infection [90-99% sensitive]).

questions.text: A girl presented with itching and oozing from an earlobe lesion after wearing nickel earrings. What test will you do to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of allergic contact dermatitis and the diagnosis is made by a patch test.

Allergic contact dermatitis is a reaction to a substance (allergen) that causes an eruption only in those individuals previously sensitized by the same molecule. It is a delayed-type of hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. It presents as pruritis and an eczematous eruption in sites where contact has taken place with the etiological agent/allergen.

Nickel is the most frequent contact allergen. Most of its salts, for example, nickel chloride and nickel sulfate, are readily soluble in water and sweat and have strong sensitizing properties. Jewelry and metal components of clothing are the usual sources of nickel in prolonged contact with the skin. 

Patch tests are used to identify the etiologic agent(s) of allergic contact dermatitis. Patches are usually applied to the back and removed 48 hours after application. The skin where the patch was applied is examined with readings taken 1 hour after removal and again 48 hours later.

The image below shows a picture of a skin patch allergy test:

 

Treatment of includes

  • Avoidance of the allergen (for example, further use of nickel‐plated objects should be avoided in this case)
  • A topical clioquinol–steroid combination can be considered as a treatment (clioquinol is known to chelate nickel)

questions.text: An intern is asked to measure the blood pressure of a patient with cardiac tamponade. He/she should ask the patient to:
questions.solution:
The patient with cardiac tamponade is asked to breathe normally to elicit pulsus paradoxus.

In a patient with cardiac tamponade, both ventricles share an incompressible pericardial covering due to the fluid. As the right ventricle enlarges during inspiration, the interventricular septum bulges into the left ventricle, reducing the left ventricular volume.

This results in reduced stroke volume and hence reduced systolic arterial pressure. 
As a result, there is a greater than normal (more than 10 mmHg) fall in systolic arterial blood pressure during inspiration, producing pulsus paradoxus.

This cannot be elicited if the patient is holding his/her breath, taking long or shallow breaths.

Pulsus paradoxus is also seen with effusive constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy and right ventricular myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: Which of the following can a 2-year-old perform?
questions.solution:
A two-year-old can walk upstairs and downstairs. 

Related Pearl: Gross motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
3 months Neck holding
5 months Rolls over
6 months Sits with support
8 months Sits without support
9 months Stands with support
12 months

Stands without support

Creeps well

Walks but falls
15 months

Walks without support

Creeps upstairs
18 months Runs
2 years Walks upstairs and downstairs (2 feet/step)
3 years

Walks upstairs with alternate foot

Rides tricycle
4 years

Walks downstairs with alternate foot

Hopping on 1 foot
5 years Can skip without falling to either side

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to the ER in an unconscious state after having collapsed in a railway station. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started, and the monitor showed asystole. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Asystole is a non-shockable rhythm. Treatment for both involves starting CPR immediately and administering 1 mg epinephrine IV.

Asystole is the complete and sustained absence of electrical activity. It is usually seen as a terminal rhythm in a resuscitation attempt that started with another rhythm, or in a patient with unwitnessed or prolonged cardiac arrest. The prognosis for persistent asystole is poor.

Another example of a non-shockable rhythm is Pulseless electrical activity. It involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: Reversible Causes of Cardiac Arrest

  • 5 H’s:
    • Hypovolemia
    • Hypoxia
    • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
    • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
    • Hypothermia
  • 5 T’s:
    • Tension pneumothorax
    • Tamponade (cardiac)
    • Toxins
    • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
    • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: Zinc is a cofactor of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Zinc acts as a cofactor for carbonic anhydrase.

Zinc is a component of many metalloenzymes including carbonic anhydrase II. Zinc also has antioxidant activity as extracellular superoxide dismutase is zinc-dependent.

Chronic zinc deficiency can cause stunted growth, hypogeusia (decreased taste sensation) hypogeusia, impaired immune function, hypogonadism and hypopigmented hair. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption.
