questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is:
questions.solution:
Gold's criteria for very severe COPD (stage IV) are FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC and FEV1 predicted are measured after the administration of a bronchodilator.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?
questions.solution:
Ventral groups of neurons fire, when forceful expiration is needed like during heavy exercise.

Dorsal group of neurons control the normal inspiration and expiration.

Pneumotaxic center limits the duration of inspiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with the following pruritic lesion 2 days after developing a fever. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base which are suggestive of herpes labialis or cold sore.

It is caused by HSV-1 (less frequently HSV-2) and commonly affects the face.

The lesions are painful and pruritic. Fever is often present which subsides in 3–5 days followed by the initial vesicular lesions becoming pustular and then crusted before healing in 7–10 days without scarring. Recurrent herpetic lesions are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.

Treatment: Oral acyclovir 200 mg and topical 5% acyclovir can be used for treatment. In case of resistance to acyclovir, foscarnet or cidofovir can be used.

Option A: Varicella presents with papules and vesicles with a centripetal distribution associated with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise.

Option C: Molluscum contagiosum presents with shiny, pearly white umbilicated papules.

Option D: Whitlow presents with painful swelling of the fingertips and periungual area due to herpes infection by inoculation.

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department having sustained severe blunt trauma to the abdomen. His vitals are Pulse:112/min, BP 80/50mmHg, GCS is 14 and the peripheries are cold.  The best diagnostic that you can perform for this patient is:
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is Ultrasound Abdomen (FAST scan -Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).

The tachycardia, cold peripheries and the BP being 80/50 mm Hg, indicate the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Hence he is not to be shifted for the sake of a CT scan and instead, a bedside FAST/E-FAST scan should be performed. 

Note: The best diagnostic modality for hemodynamically stable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is CT Scan.

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage for zinc supplements in children with diarrhea?

choices.text: 20 mg of zinc daily for infants < 12 months of age for 10-14 days
20 mg of zinc for children > 6 months of age for 7 days
10 mg of zinc for children > 12 months of age for 20 days
10 mg of zinc for children < 6 months of age for 10-14 days

questions.solution:
According to WHO and UNICEF, 10 mg of zinc is given to infants < 6 months of age for 10-14 days.

20 mg of Zinc is given to infants > 6 months of age for 10-14 days during an episode of acute diarrhoea. This is done to reduce the duration and severity of the episode and prevent recurrence in the following months.

Intensified Diarrhea Control Fortnight : The goal is to attain zero child deaths due to childhood diarrhea. The overall objective of IDCF is to ensure high coverage of ORS and Zinc use rates in children with diarrhoea. It also complements awareness activities (including Swachh) for prevention and management of diarrhoea in under-five children.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of chest pain and collapsed and was later declared brought dead by the hospital. His family says he was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden heart failure in a previously healthy person under a stressful situation is suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients can present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

ECHO reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a Takotsubo (pot for catching octopus).  The ECG changes can mimic myocardial infarction but changes extend beyond a particular coronary arterial territory. Coronary angiography, therefore, may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. (Option B)

It is a self-limiting disorder resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning resembling a Takotsubo pot. 

Other options:

Option A: Infective cardiomyopathy: The most common causes of infective myocarditis are viral infections and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is associated with Chagas' disease. Acute viral myocarditis often presents with symptoms and signs of heart failure, although it can also manifest as chest pain and show electrocardiogram (ECG) changes resembling pericarditis or acute myocardial infarction. In Chagas' disease, specific features include abnormalities in the conduction system, particularly dysfunction of the sinus node and AV node, as well as the right bundle branch block.

Option C: Dilated cardiomyopathy: It is the most common cardiomyopathy and is predominantly characterised by systolic dysfunction. Though it may present acutely, it progresses chronically. The familial form is due to mutations in TTN gene which encode the sarcomeric protein titin. Other etiologocal agents include alcohol, infective myocarditis, doxorubicin, hemochromatosis and sarcoidosis. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder and is a prominent cause of sudden death before the age of 35 years. Family history is commonly present, a sarcomere mutation is present in ~50% of patients. Sudden death can be due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation. Risk factors for sudden death in this disease include young age, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, failure of blood pressure to increase during exercise, recent (within 6 months) syncope, ventricular wall thickness >3 cm, and possibly the severity of LV outflow obstruction.

questions.text: The following is the finding noted in a 12-month-old baby who is growing well and developing normally since birth. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this finding?

choices.text: Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy should be suspected
Chromosomal analysis should be done to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities

questions.solution:
The picture depicts a Simian crease – a single transverse palmar crease. It is a normal finding in about 3% of the population. In a child with simian crease and normal growth and development, reassurance should be provided. 

  • A simian crease is one of the findings of Down's syndrome however presence of only this finding should not lead to a diagnosis of Down's syndrome.
  • Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy does not lead to this finding. However, maternal alcohol intake can be associated with this condition.
  • Chromosomal analysis in an otherwise well child is not indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil
The vision is normal in right eye
Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes

questions.solution:
The given image of "swinging flashlight test" shows both pupils constricting when the left eye is stimulated (normal response) followed by both pupils abnormally dilating when the right eye is stimulated (abnormal response).

This finding is suggestive of Marcus Gunn pupil which is also known as Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).

In this patient the right eye is defective (Option A) and the left eye is normal (rules out option B).

Marcus Gunn pupil refers to the paradoxical response of the pupil to light and it is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease such as optic neuritis or optic nerve damage in glaucoma.It is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex in one eye.

Normal response to stimulation of the eye is constriction of the pupil of the stimulated eye (direct light reflex) and also of the contralateral eye (indirect or consensual light reflex).

Causes of RAPD:

  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g.All types of optic neuritis, glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)
  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )

The below given image depicts the findings seen in Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD).

Option A:Argyl Robertson pupil is seen in neurosyphilis. In this condition,on light stimulation both the pupils will not constrict, but on accommodation (near target) both the pupils will constrict.

Argyll Robertson pupil is attributed to a dorsal midbrain lesion of neurosyphilis that affects the pupillary light pathway but spares the more ventrally placed pupillary near reflex pathway(Accomdation pathway), thereby causing a light-near dissociation.

Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) include:

  • Bilateral small, irregular pupils in dim light
  • Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP)- The eye accomdates by constricting the pupil for a near target.
  • Light Reflex absent: pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light.
  • Cocaine eye drops(mydriatics) induced mydriasis.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics bind to the subunit of the ribosome marked by the black arrow and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline binds to the 30S subunit of the ribosome and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.

Protein synthesis is important for maintaining certain vital functions in bacteria. Hence by interrupting the protein synthesis, they act as bacteriostatic agents.

Antibacterial which binds to the 30s subunit of 70s ribosome.

  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides

Antibacterials that bind to 50s subunit of 70s ribosome.

  • Macrolides
  • Clindamycin
  • Streptogramins
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Linezolid

questions.text: King’s College selection criteria for liver transplantation in Non-paracetamol induced acute liver failure does not include:
questions.solution:
King’s College selection criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure

Paracetamol induced

  • pH <7.30 (irrespective of grade of encephalopathy)
  • OR prothrombin time (PT) >100 s + serum creatinine >300 μmol/L + grade 3 or 4 encephalopathy.

Non-paracetamol induced (irrespective of encephalopathy)

PT >100 s or any three of the following:

  • Age <10 years or >40 years
  • Aetiology non-A, non-B, halothane or idiosyncratic drug reaction
  • More than 7 days’ jaundice before encephalopathy
  • PT >50 s
  • Bilirubin >300 μmol/L

questions.text: A patient from a North-Eastern state was diagnosed to have an infection with P. falciparum malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North-Eastern states is artemether (20 mg) plus lumefantrine (120 mg).

As per National Vector Borne Disease Control Program (NVBDCP): 

  • Plasmodium malariae: treat as Plasmodium falciparum
  • Plasmodium ovale: treat as Plasmodium vivax
  • Severe and complicated malaria

            -Initial parenteral treatment x 24-48 hr:  quinine/artemether/artesunate/arteether

            -Oral treatment after 48 hrs-after parenteral quinine: quinine + doxycyclinex 7 days or quinine + clindamycin x 7 days (pregnancy and chidren<8yrs)

            -After parenteral artemisinin derivates: in NE states: ACT -AL X 3 days+primaquine (day2), in other states: ACT-SPX 3 days+primaquine (day 2) 

  • Chemoprophylaxis

                       Short-term, less than or equal to 6 weeks: Doxycycline OD (start one day before travel and continue for 4 weeks after return)

                        Long-term, more than 6 weeks: mefloquine weekly (start 2 weeks before travel and 4 weeks after return).

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: You notice the following lesion in the forearm of an otherwise normal newborn. The lesion is caused because of:

choices.text: A viral infection transmitted from mother to the fetus
A bacterial infection transmitted from the mother to the fetus
Vigorous in utero sucking upon the affected part
An autoimmune condition in the newborn

questions.solution:
The image shows Sucking Blisters.
Sucking blisters are caused due to vigorous in utero sucking on the affected part.

They are usually present upon the upper-limb.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of:
questions.solution:
Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Alcohol and its metabolites, especially acetaldehyde have a direct toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy:

  • Acquired causes :
    • Infectious and non-infectious myocarditis: most common cause globally
    • Alcohol is the most common cause in India
    • Pregnancy:
      • Pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM)
      • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM)
    • Stress-induced: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
    • Drug-induced:
      • Doxorubicin (anthracycline)
      • Trastuzumab 
      • Cyclophosphamide
    • Nutritional deficiency:
      • Beriberi (thiamine),
      • Keshan disease (selenium),
      • Carnitine deficiency
    • Endocrine: Hypo and hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus
    • Others:
      • Cobalt toxicity,
      • Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)
  • Familial causes (50%): 
    • Mutation in the cardiac myocyte titin gene
    • Haemochromatosis
    • Syndromes: Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker’s muscular dystrophy

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found in his garden confused and somnolent. He was outside trimming the hedges with an electric cutter on a hot summer day for about 2-3 hours prior to being found by his wife. He has a history of mild-moderate systolic heart failure, and his medications include atorvastatin, metoprolol and losartan. He works as a TSA officer in the airport. On examination, he is difficult to arouse and confused, with a heart rate of 120 bpm, BP of 100/50 mmHg saturation of 97% on room air, and a temperature of 105-degree Fahrenheit. His skin is dry and warm with the rest of the physical examination unremarkable. His laboratory studies are notable for a sodium of 146 mEq/L, potassium of 3.8mEq/L, creatinine kinase of 250 U/L, glucose of 120 mg/L, BUN of 35 mg/dL, and creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Classic heatstroke is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

Heatstroke:

  • The classical manifestations of heat stroke reflect a total loss of thermoregulatory function. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure.
  • Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, the historical and physical triad of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature of more than 104.9-degree Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) helps establish the preliminary diagnosis.
  • Heat exhaustion is distinguished from heatstroke by the loss of thermoregulatory control, typically manifested by a core body temperature of > 40.5-degree C, in case of heat stroke. The physiologic precipitants of heat exhaustion are water and sodium depletion.
  • There are two forms of heat stroke with different manifestations:
CLASSIC HEAT STROKE EXERTIONAL HEAT STROKE
Older patients Younger patient
Predisposing health factors/medications Healthy condition
Epidemiology (heat waves) Sporadic cases
Sedentary Exercising
Anhidrosis (possible) Diaphoresis (common)
CNS dysfunction Myocardial/hepatic injury
Oliguria Acute renal failure
Coagulopathy (mild) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Mild lactic acidosis Marked lactic acidosis
Mild creatinine kinase elevation Rhabdomyolysis
Normoglycemia/Calcaemia Hypoglycemia/Calcemia
Normokalemia Hyperkalemia

Other options:

  • The absence of focal neurological findings, elevated creatinine kinase (normal range=25-200 U/L), and precipitating medications make the other mentioned diagnoses less likely.

questions.text: Prolonged aPTT and normal PT are seen in patients with all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation is associated with prolonged PT and prolonged aPTT.

Conditions with prolonged aPTT can be classified on the basis of the bleeding symptoms:

  • No bleeding symptoms: deficiency of Factor XII, prekallikrein, HMW kininogen, lupus anticoagulant
  • Mild bleeding symptoms: Factor XI deficiency
  • Severe bleeding symptoms: Hemophilia, von Willebrand disease

Lupus anticoagulant is an antiphospholipid antibody that interferes with aPTT test and causes its prolongation. It is corrected by adding excess phospholipid.

The clinical manifestation of lupus anticoagulant is thrombosis. Confirmatory tests are dilute Russell's viper venom test and kaolin clotting time.

questions.text: What does the following image show?
questions.solution:
The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage.

The cells frequently involved are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Both the cells are viable and there are no physiological and morphological consequences to either of them.

questions.text: The patient presents with pigmentation of the face as shown in the image below and gradually increasing backache and stiffness. The X-ray image of the spine is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical images show the accumulation of blackish discoloration on the face and the X-Ray shows calcification of the intervertebral discs. These findings are associated with alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is a condition caused due to the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. This results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

This condition is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Black ochronotic pigmentation (Alkapton bodies) of cartilage and collagenous tissue
  • Homogentisic aciduria (patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing)
  • Large joint arthritis
  • Calcification of intervertebral discs known as as ochronotic spondyloarthropathy

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Upper Motor Neuron type of paralysis below the lesion on the opposite side
Impaired fine touch below the lesion on the opposite side
Loss of crude touch below the lesion on the same side
Loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side

questions.solution:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
  • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla).
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: The probable diagnosis based on the below clinical image of the breast is?
questions.solution:
The image shows a thrombosed subcutaneous cord attached to the skin of the breast which is the pathognomic feature of Mondor's Disease.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. It may also occur in the arm or penis. On raising the arm, the skin over the chest gets stretched and a narrow, shallow groove alongside the cord is seen. It is treated by restricting arm movements and usually subsides within a few months without recurrence, complications, or deformity.

The differential diagnosis to be considered is lymphatic permeation from an occult carcinoma of the breast.

Other options:

Option A: Paget’s disease is a type of ductal carcinoma in situ arising from the nipple and commonly presents as nipple erosion.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Option D: Tietze’s syndrome refers to the benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

questions.text: Identify the parasite based on the image of its egg given below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a bile stained egg of whipworm.

Egg of whipworm (Trichuris trichiura):

  • Barrel shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing a non-segmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • The egg has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown
  • The eggs float in saturated salt solution.
  • Eggs are not infective for humans.

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 40-year old woman underwent routine mammographic screening for breast cancer. The radiologist reported the mammographic lesion found as BIRADS grade 3. This categorization implies that the lesion has a _______% chance of being malignant.
questions.solution:
A lesion reported as BIRADS grade 3, has a <2% chance of being malignant. 

BIRADS Grade:

  • Grade 3: >0% but ≤2% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 4:
    • 4a: >2% to ≤10% chance of being malignant
    • 4b: >10% to ≤50% chance of being malignant
    • 4c: >50% to <95% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 5: ≥95% chance of being malignant

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy

questions.text:
A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On third day she came back with fever, tachycardia and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. 
Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation likely suggests Cortical Vein Thrombosis.

Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage 

There are no focal deficits hence unlikely.

Option B - Meningitis 

  • It would have presented with neck rigidity / photophobia.
  • Moreover , presence of early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

Option C - Acute Migraine

  • Migraine does not present with seizures.
  • Hence most likely diagnosis is  Cortical Vein Thrombosis.

Cortical Vein thrombosis          

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pro thrombotic conditions

Clinical presentation

  • Highly variable
  • Head ache is the most common symptom.
  • With or without
    • Vomiting
    • Papilledema
    • Focal deficits

Investigation

  • Brain MRI with MR venography – most sensitive
  • CT – normal in 30 % of cases.

questions.text: All of the following can be done to remove confounders except:
questions.solution:
Blinding does not eliminate confounding factors. Blinding is done to eliminate the bias (such as subject bias, observer bias, or investigator bias).
 
A confounding factor is defined as the one associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups.
 
  • For example, a prospective study is being conducted to know the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. 
  • However, individuals who drink alcohol are most likely to smoke. So, smoking is associated with the exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. Thus, smoking is a confounding factor.
  • In the above example, if the study is conducted without eliminating the confounding factor, then the result may falsely suggest that alcohol is a causative factor for lung cancer. 
 
Techniques to eliminate confounding factors include
  • Randomization
  • Matching
  • Stratified randomization
  • Restriction
 
Randomization is the random allocation of the participants in experimental studies (Ex.randomized control trial) into the study group and control group.
 
Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (for example, case–control and cohort studies), is the process where the participants in two groups are matched based on factors such as age, gender, race, smoking status, etc. to eliminate the potential confounders.
 
Stratified randomization, which is also known as prestratification or blocking, is the process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups which internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants form each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.
 
Restriction: This method restricts the study to only those participants with particular characteristics. For example, a study can be restricted to participants of only one gender, race, age group, geographical area, disease severity, etc., thus eliminating the potential confounders.

questions.text: A nuclear disaster occurs in your state. Which of the following drugs is given prophylactically?
questions.solution:
After a nuclear disaster, Potassium Iodide (KI) is given prophylactically to all people exposed/at risk of exposure to radiation. If taken in time and at the appropriate dosage, KI blocks the thyroid gland uptake of radioactive iodine and thus, reduces the risk of thyroid cancers.

Table salt (while it contains KI), does not contain enough iodine to block uptake of radioactive iodine by the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A boy caught his leg against a solid obstacle while falling. The image shows his post repair x ray. Which of the following is an accurate description of the procedure done?
questions.solution:
The image depicts tension band wiring in a figure of 8 configuration.

The mechanism of injury described in the question, leg caught against a solid obstacle while falling, causes forceful contraction of quadriceps -> transverse fracture with gap between fragments.

Tension Band wiring is used in  fixation of transverse Patellar Fractures.

Though k wires are being used, the more appropriate answer to the question would be Tension Band Wiring.

In this, two K wires are used to transfix the reduced patellar fragments and a flexible wire is  looped around them tightly.

 

AP and Lateral view X Rays of tension band wiring.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient came back to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the next best step?

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.solution: The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by drainage of fluid collections by pigtail insertion and administration of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics.

questions.text: Denosumab a monoclonal antibody against RANKL receptor is used in the treatment of
questions.solution:
• Denosumab is used in the treatment of osteoporosis.
  • RANK-RANKL interaction is necessary for osteoclastogenesis.
  • This drug interrupts the RANKL–RANK interaction and thus reduces osteoclastic activity and bone resorption.

Uses of Denosumab:

  1. Osteoporosis
  2. Aromatase Inhibitor Induced Bone Loss
  3. Androgen Deprivation Induced Bone Loss
  4. Glucocorticoid-Induced Osteoporosis
  5. Multiple myelomas and  bone metastases from solid tumors
  6. Giant Cell Tumor
  7. Hypercalcemia of Malignancy

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina.
questions.solution:
The inner plexiform layer is the marked layer in the given histological image of retina, identified as the fourth layer from the uppermost (innermost) layer.

The retina consists of 10 layers. The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is the outermost layer - below the Bruch's membrane of the choroid - and the internal limiting membrane is the innermost layer - separating the retina from the vitreous.

The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of cells containing pigment. It is separated from the neurosensory retinal layers by the potential space between them which is known as interphotoreceptor matrix. 

The inner plexiform layer consists of synapsing nerve fibers. The axons of bipolar cells synapse with dendrites of ganglion cells; and both these processes synapse with processes of amacrine cells. It also contains some horizontally placed internal plexiform cells; and also a few ganglion cells.

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following amyloid protein is accumulated in a case of chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
In a case of chronic renal failure, Aβ2m accumulates.

Other options:

  • AA: Secondary amyloidosis (Chronic inflammatory conditions)
  • AL: Primary amyloidosis (Multiple myeloma)
  • ATTR: Systemic senile amyloidosis

questions.text: An autopsy was performed to find the cause of death of a person brought dead to the casualty and it showed a fracture of the thyroid cartilage and bruising around the neck. The cause of death is?
questions.solution:
Both bruising around the neck and the fracture of the thyroid cartilage are findings seen in throttling. Throttling/manual strangulation is when bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate.


Mechanism of death:

  • Occlusion of blood vessels supplying blood to the brain (carotid arteries).
  • Occlusion to airway probably plays a minor role if any, in causing death
  • Carotid sinus pressure may result in vagus nerve stimulation, resulting in cardiac arrest (vagal inhibition)

Autopsy findings:

  • Bruising of neck: due to the grasping of the neck by the assailant.
  • Abrasions on the neck: fingernail marks from assailant or victim
  • Fracture of thyroid cartilage
  • Inward fracture of greater cornu of the hyoid bone.

questions.text: Prosopagnosia is
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces

  • Autotopagnosia -  inability to recognize or to orient any part of one's own body
  • Simultagnosia - inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some elements of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole
  • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one’s own or another’s body
  • Tactile agnosia (aka stereognosia) -  inability to recognize objects by touch, in the presence of intact cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table?

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip

questions.solution:
The position of the patient in the Cesarean section is supine, with a wedge under the right hip.

The wedge beneath the right hip creates a left lateral tilt to aid venous return and avoid hypotension.

questions.text: Acid Citrate Dextrose (ACD), used to store blood, preserves the RBCs for a period of 21 days. The storage period when adding phosphate alone and when adding adenine and phosphate together to ACD would respectively be?
questions.solution:
The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

When adding phosphate to ACD, Citrate Phosphate Dextrose (CPD) is formed – It has a storage period of 21 days. There is no change in the shelf life as phosphate only increases the 2,3 DPG levels of the stored blood.

When adding both phosphate and adenine to ACD, Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine (CPDA-1) is formed. It has a storage period of 35 days. It increases the shelf life by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs.

Using additive solutions containing saline, adenine, and glucose, with or without mannitol (SAGM) decreases RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

questions.text: A 42-year-old epileptic patient is posted for general anesthesia. Which of the following is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures as it further increases ICP and also causes delirium and hallucinations.

Ketamine:

  • Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures.
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate, intracranial tension is highly raised.
  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion etc)

Thiopentone:

  • Agent of choice for cerebral protection
  • Anticonvulsant action due to the phenyl group

Propofol:

  • Decreases ICP
  • Neuroprotective

Midazolam:

  •   Used in treating seizures

questions.text: A 5-year-old child requires bronchodilator therapy. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following is false about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Systemic absorption of drugs is unaffected

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spacer device. It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects like dysphonia that occur with the use of a pMDI.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. The systemic absorption is unchanged by the use of a spacer.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.

The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

  • Pressurized metered-dose inhalers - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of a drug
  • Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children <7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 
  • Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -
    • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
    • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated blood uric acid levels, and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch 
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Allopurinol should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Hers disease (GSD VI). Patients usually present in early childhood with hepatomegaly and growth retardation. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.

Option B: Phosphorylase kinase deficiency leads to Type IX GSD. Phosphorylase kinase is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. It presents in the first 2 years of life with short stature and hepatomegaly. Unlike GSD I, lactic acidosis, bleeding tendency, and loose bowel movements are not characteristic.

Option C: Liver glycogen synthase deficiency leads to Type 0 GSD. It presents in infancy with early-morning drowsiness, pallor, vomiting, fatigue, and sometimes convulsions. Hypoglycemia, hyperketonemia, and low lactate levels are seen. There is no hyperlipidemia or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Services provided by the establishment bearing the following logo is  ________
questions.solution:
The given logo is of Suraksha clinics, where color-coded STI/RTI (sexually transmitted infections/Reproductive tract infections) kits are provided.

The NACO has branded the STI/RTI services as Suraksha Clinic and it has developed a communication strategy for generating demand for these services.

The kits are:

  • Kit 1– grey, for urethra discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis
  • Kit 2 – green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3 – white, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4 – blue, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 5 – red, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 6 – yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7 – black, for inguinal bubo

Note: Anti retroviral therapy is given at ART centres under the National Aids Control Program- IV.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children but an affected female always has affected children. Type of inheritance?
questions.solution:
In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.
 
The mitochondrial inheritance pattern is as shown in the image below:
The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria.
 
The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa has very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.
 
Therefore, affected mother transmits the disease to all the offsprings (both male and female), and only the daughters of the affected mother, will further transmit the disease.
 
Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on the oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.
  • There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondria, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondria  This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 
  • The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction, called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.
  • Also, during a cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests:
questions.solution:
The image of FAST in a trauma patient suggests Positive FAST as there is a fluid collection in the abdominal cavity. The thin anechoic area located between the liver(on the left) and the Kidney(on the right) is a collection of fluid visualized in this RUQ Sonogram image. 

 

FAST stands for Focused assessment with sonography for trauma. It is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique:

  • Patient in the supine position
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer
  • Following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan may be performed: left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

 

Sequentially order of FAST is:- pericardial sac, the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ), Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ), and pelvis.

4 ‘Ps’ are evaluated in sequence: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

 

Note:-

In Pneumoperitoneum, air is collected in the peritoneal cavity which is usually hyperechoic not anechoic and would appear white in the ultrasound image.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: A female patient comes to you with complaints of midline neck swelling. You proceed to perform the thyroid examination and ask her to swallow. The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

  • Parotid gland
  • Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of dapsone, considering that it is used in the treatment of leprosy, fungal infections and, also for immunomodulatory actions?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of dapsone is inhibition of folic acid synthesis.

Dapsone [4,4‐diaminodiphenylsulphone (DDS)] is a structural analog of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway. It is weakly bactericidal and can cause mild hemolysis, and rarely anemia or psychosis.

DDS syndrome is a rare side effect of dapsone therapy in leprosy patients which starts after 5-6 weeks of starting dapsone and leads to exfoliative dermatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and hepatitis and may be fatal. It is also called 'five-week dermatitis'.

questions.solution:
The marked structure is foramen ovale and mandibular nerve passes through it.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does this capnographic waveform appear?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing.

Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted soda lime or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems.

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia shows progressive rise in ETCO2 

Option B: Bronchospasm shows a shark fin appearance

Option D: Accidental extubation shows flat ETCO2 trace

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Hormone replacement therapy is not indicated for:
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy is not indicated in coronary artery disease prophylaxis. There is currently insufficient evidence to recommend the initiation or continuation of either estrogen therapy (ET) or estrogen-progestin therapy (EPT) for the prevention of primary or secondary coronary heart disease (CHD). 

In an 18-year reevaluation of WHI (women health initiative) participants, it was found that cardiovascular, cancer, and all-cause mortality rates were essentially the same in both the hormone therapy (HT) and placebo groups.

Currently, hormone therapy (HT) is only indicated for the treatment of bothersome vasomotor symptoms (VMS) and genitourinary symptoms, prevention of osteoporosis, and treatment of hypoestrogenism caused by hypogonadism, surgical menopause, or premature ovarian insufficiency. 

Estrogen should not be used in women with the following conditions: 

  • undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • active or prior stroke, myocardial infarction, or transient ischemic attack (TIA)
  • known thrombophilia, liver dysfunction, or disease
  • untreated hypertension
  • known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • known or suspected pregnancy

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

Newer researches and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria that causes the phenomenon shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given picture shows swarming, which is exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively by means of peritrichous flagella, resulting in “swarming” on solid media. It can be suppressed by

  • Phenylethyl alcohol
  • Cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with complaints of acute abdominal pain. A plain X-ray abdomen erect was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray clearly shows the presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas in the right upper quadrant. This indicates pneumoperitoneum.

Causes of pneumoperitoneum include:

  1. Bowel perforation
    1. Peptic ulcer
    2. Ischemic bowel
    3. Necrotizing enterocolitis.
  2. Small bowel perforation
    1. Trauma
    2. Penetrating injuries
  3. During surgery / laparoscopy

Signs of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs
    • Double wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign or gas-relief sign)
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign)
  • Peritoneal ligament-related signs
    • Football sign
    • Falciform ligament sign
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign)
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Cupola sign
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Morison's pouch sign (doge cap sign)
    • Periportal free gas sign

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at  ______.
questions.solution:
Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

questions.text: This kind of apraxia is typical of Alzheimer's disease, when an act can be performed in isolation, but a series of acts cannot be executed as a whole in an organised manner. The apraxia is known as:
questions.solution:
Ideational apraxia occurs when the individual components of a sequence of skilled acts can be performed in isolation, but the entire series cannot be organized and executed as a whole.

  • For example, the sequence of opening an envelope, removing the letter, unfolding it, and placing it on the table cannot be performed in order, even though the individual acts can be performed in isolation.
  • A lesion in the left parietal cortex and prefrontal cortex (responsible for sequencing and execution) causes ideational apraxia.
  • This apraxia is a typical finding of diffuse cortical degeneration, such as Alzheimer's disease.

Apraxia:

The skilful use of the hands is called praxis, and deficits in skilled movements are termed apraxias.

The three levels of apraxia are:

Limb-kinetic -

  • Inability to use the contralateral hand even though there is strength.
  • A lesion in the supplementary motor area causes limb-kinetic apraxia.

Ideomotor -

  • Inability to do an act on command, despite preserved comprehension, strength, and spontaneous performance of the same act.
  • Disconnection of the Wernicke's area (language comprehension) from the motor regions causes ideomotor apraxia.

Ideational or conceptual apraxia -

  • Inability to perform a sequence of acts as a whole.
  • A lesion in the left parietal cortex and prefrontal cortex causes ideational apraxia.

Constructional apraxia -

  • Inability of patients to copy accurately drawings or three-dimensional constructions.
  • It is a common disorder after right parietal stroke, often persisting after initial problems such as visuospatial neglect have resolved.

questions.text: Which of the following is the color of vacutainer containing sodium fluoride as a content?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride is present in the grey coloured tube.

Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis. Hence, is used for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: The sebaceous gland releases its secretions by:
questions.solution:
The sebaceous gland is a holocrine gland, which is depicted by image C.

Types of glands based on the mode of secretion:

Sebaceous glands are located in the dermis. Usually, each gland opens into a hair follicle via a broad duct which drains multiple pear-shaped alveoli. Some glands exist independent of the hair follicle as well, in which case they open directly onto the skin surface. 

Types of glands:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine (Merocrine)
Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis
Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands) and eyelids (glands of Moll)

Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland 

Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola

Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce

Fordyce' spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa

Eg: Sweat glands on palms and soles

Found everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips

questions.text: The cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, the supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. And often patients respond well to supportive management.

Platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding.

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs in dengue include 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised to all patient of dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of ____
questions.solution:
Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery. 

The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:

Uterine artery→Arcuate artery→Radial artery→Basal artery→Spiral artery

questions.text: A housewife from rural Tripura with a past history of infectious mononucleosis presents with complaints of double vision and a neck swelling that has progressively increased in size. She also gives a history of nasal discharge and is annoyed that her husband is recently complaining of a change in her voice. What is the most likely speech pattern observed here?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of exposure to EBV, progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal discharge, diplopia (involvement of cranial nerve VI), and change in voice is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The most likely speech pattern, in this case, is rhinolalia clausa or denasal speech, due to obstruction of the nasopharynx by the tumor.

Rhinolalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words resonated in the nasal cavity and is usually seen due to blockage of nose or nasopharynx

Other nasal symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma are:

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Nasal discharge
  • Epistaxis

Option B- Rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal voice) is seen in Velopharyngeal insufficiency.

Option C- Puberphonia is the persistence of prepubertal voice into adolescence or adulthood. 

Option D- Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases.

The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affected blood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.

Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, which characteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows the appearance of the rash. 

Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, along with the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may show nonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies and biopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic information

Treatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition. Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement. Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severe disease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinal problems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP is favorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and manage potential complications.

questions.text: Primary level of prevention for specific protection includes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Handwashing is not a specific protection measure under primary prevention. All other options are protection measures against specific diseases. 

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Late stage of disease
