questions.text: Mass vaccination is most effective in which of​ the following outbreaks?
questions.solution:
Mass immunization is effective in case of an outbreak of poliomyelitis.
 
The WHO has laid down standard operating procedures to be followed for responding to a poliovirus event or outbreak.
 
In the case of detection of an event or outbreak, the WHO recommends the following step-wise approach:
  1. Notification of the disease to international health regulations (IHR) focal point at the WHO regional centre.
  2. Detailed investigation and risk assessment.
  3. Enhanced surveillance to detect ongoing person-person transmission.
  4. Vaccination response to reach every child.
 
The vaccination response includes:
  1. A rapid response (RR) vaccination campaign: This campaign is initiated with 14 days of the laboratory sequencing result and targets the immediate area of the virus isolation to rapidly stop further transmission. The target population is about 2 lakh to 5 lakh children.
  2. Supplementary immunization activities (SIA): Two high-quality large-scale SIA campaigns (SIA1and SIA2) are carried out, to ensure that >90% of children are vaccinated. These campaigns should be completed within 8 weeks of laboratory sequencing result. The target population in the large scale rounds is about 2 million children.
  3. Mop-up round or additional SIAs: If the monitoring suggests that children have been missed in certain areas, then a mop-up round of immunization is done.
 
The target age group for immunization under SIAs is children less than five years of age. If there is evidence of virus circulation among older age groups, then the target age group can be expanded to 10 or 15 years or even to the whole population depending on the local context.
 
Other options:
Options a: In case of a cholera outbreak, the mainstay of response includes health education on the role of hygiene, rehydration therapy, and sanitation measures.
Option b: The mainstay of typhoid control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Although WHO recommends immunization as a complementary method to the above measures, there is insufficient data to ascertain the effectiveness of vaccination in case of a typhoid outbreak.
Option d: In case of measles outbreak, the control measures include isolation for seven days after the onset of rash and immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiparous women >40yrs, presenting with abdominal mass (free from adnexa) and myometrial cysts on MRI, point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and sometimes dyspareunia. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. 

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) reveals a salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

Other options:

Option A: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the endometrial lining (uterus). They usually present as dysmenorrhea and lower dull abdominal pain. Vaginal examination reveals a tender fixed retroverted uterus. They can be managed medically (oral contraceptives, aromatase inhibitors, etc)  and surgically (if failed medical management). Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is performed in advanced cases.

Option C: Leiomyoma (fibroid) is the commonest benign tumor arising from the uterus. They present as abnormal uterine bleeding, infertility, and abdominal pain. On bimanual examination, the uterus is enlarged and the mass moves with the cervix. It can be managed medically (mifepristone or newer progesterone) and surgically. A myomectomy is performed for large fibroids with significant symptoms.

Option D: Endometrial hyperplasia can be simple, glandular, or atypical. They are seen in women with estrogen excess states like obesity, PCOD, or on tamoxifen therapy. They usually present as abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria?
questions.solution:
Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

As Mupirocin has no structural similarities with existing systemic antibiotics that might lead to the development of cross-resistance and has minimal toxicity in its topical form, it is approved for the prevention of MRSA outbreaks

Mixed therapy with systemic agents is not preferred as it would cause unnecessary antibiotic exposure potentially paving way for drug resistance. 

Mupirocin is a unique antimicrobial agent because of its structure and mechanism of action. Mupirocin exerts its antimicrobial activity by reversibly inhibiting isoleucyl-transfer RNA, thereby inhibiting bacterial protein and RNA synthesis.

questions.text: The baby is in which station?
questions.solution:
The head of the fetus it at the level of ischial spines. So it is in station 0.

  • The fetal station, that is the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal, is described in relation to the ischial spines. These spines lie halfway between the pelvic inlet and the pelvic outlet. When the lowermost portion of the presenting fetal part is at the level of the ischial spines, it is designated to be in zero station.
  • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines the designation is -5,-4, -3,-2,-1 then 0 station.
  • Below the spines, the presenting part passes +1,+2,+3,+4,+5 stations. Station +5 corresponds to the fetal head is visible at the level of introitus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of sensation over the marked area. Which nerve may be damaged?
questions.solution:
The skin over the angle of the mandible is innervated by the great auricular nerve.

Most of the skin covering the face is innervated solely by branches of the trigeminal nerve except the skin over the angle of the mandible which is supplied by the great auricular nerve from the C2 cervical plexus and the ear supplied by the vagus nerve, the facial nerve, and the cervical plexus.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty with circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs. An emergency escharotomy is planned by the attending surgeon. Which of the following incision would be made by the surgeon?

choices.text: Depends upon the limb in involved

questions.solution:
Circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs require emergency escharotomy.

The tourniquet effect of this injury is easily treated by incising the whole length of full-thickness burns. This should be done in the mid-axial line, avoiding major nerves.

Key features of escharotomy placement in limbs:

Upper limb: Mid-axial, anterior to the elbow medially to avoid the ulnar nerve

Hand: Midline in the digits. Release muscle compartments if tight. Best done in theatre and with an experienced surgeon

Lower limb: Mid-axial. Posterior to the ankle medially to avoid the saphenous vein.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to casualty in an unconscious state after a head injury. What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The sign seen in the image is the battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over the mastoid process.

Skull base fractures are associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Tympanic membrane rupture
  • Battle sign: Bruising or ecchymosis behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Other options:

Option A-Duret hemorrhages are delayed secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Option B- Kernohan phenomenon is an imaging finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in an indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Option D- Racoon eyes refer to bilateral periorbital bruising, seen in anterior cranial fossa fractures. (image given below)

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman on HRT presented with abdominal pain for the past 6 months. On examination, a non-tender, right adnexal mass was palpable. USG showed a 3 x 3 cm smooth ovarian cyst. What is the next best step in her case?

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirmation of USG findings by CT scan
Exploratory laparotomy for evaluation of cyst
CA- 125 level estimation; if normal, advise regular follow-up

questions.solution:
CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for post-menopausal ovarian cysts.

Management includes the following:

  • Calculation of Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) = U x  M  x  Ca-125, where
    • U = ultrasound score
    • M = menopausal status
    • Ca 125 = serum levels
  • Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200.

Option B - CT scan is not recommended for initial evaluation. It is done only for further evaluation and when RMI > 200.

questions.text: Jack knife position causes death due to:
questions.solution:
Jack-knife position leads to positional asphyxia.

It is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.

questions.text: You notice the resident performing Pre-oxygenation before induction,  in a patient with an adequate respiratory drive. He would be performing the preoxygenation for how much time?
questions.solution:
Pre-oxygenation (Denitrogenation) before induction should be given for 3 minutes.

The aim of pre-oxygenation before induction is to improve the oxygen reservoir of the lungs by replacing Nitrogen with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes.

In case of emergency conditions where affording 3 minutes is life-threatening, then, the patient is asked to take 4-5 deep breaths with 100% oxygen as an alternative.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: A 28-yr old man has recently finished a half- marathon. He complains of pain along the anterior and medial aspect of the tibia which increases on jogging & walking for a long time. Plain X-Ray radiograph of the leg was found to be normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with a history of lower limb overuse (marathon running) and pain along the medial tibial border which increases with activity (jogging and long walks), along with a normal radiograph, suggests medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS), also known as shin splints.

MTSS is a stress injury of the tibia which occurs due to the frequent overuse of lower limbs. It is commonly seen in athletes and military personnel.

Exercise-induced pain along the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border is typical. Since it is a stress injury, the radiograph of the leg appears normal.

Management is mainly conservative with rest and activity modification with less repetitive and load-bearing exercises.

questions.text: NADPH is used in ______.
questions.solution:
NADPH is the source of reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis.

 This NADPH is derived from 3 sources:

  • HMP shunt pathway (main source)
  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Reducing agents

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis 

Fatty acid chain elongation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation of aromatic compounds, steroids, alcohols, and drugs

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Glycolysis & Krebs cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

β- Oxidation of fatty acid

Catalyzes reactions in muscle and liver cells

Electron Transport Chain

FADH2

Krebs cycle

Electron Transport Chain

Oxidative Phosphorylation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylase cycle

β-Oxidation of fatty acid

questions.text: A 5-year-old child brought to the OPD with painless deformity. Given is the image of the X-ray of the child. Which of the following is not likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of rickets. Pelkan spur is not seen in rickets.  

Pelkan spurs are metaphyseal spurs with marginal fractures. It is a radiographic finding seen in scurvy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.solution:
The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca laterally.

The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia lying immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament. It extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) superolaterally and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

Attachments:

  • Medially, its fibres insert by a broad attachment into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, behind the conjoint tendon. 
  • Laterally, its fibres fan out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliaca without bony attachment to the iliac spines. 

Clinical note: It is considered as an important landmark in laparoscopic hernia surgeries.

questions.text: An intubated patient is on the ventilator in an ICU. An intern who is to calculate the GCS score recognizes that the patient opens eyes to verbal command and is able to withdraw when a painful stimulus is applied. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is
questions.solution:
The GCS score of the patient in the above scenario is E3 VNT M4.

Analyzing the GCS score of the above patient,

  • Eye opening to verbal commands – 3
  • Verbal response – NT (NT stands for Not testable, as the patient is intubated)
  • Motor response – withdrawal to pain – 4

In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as ‘not testable,’ NT.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy?
questions.solution:
A saturated salt solution is used commonly for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy.

Rectified spirit is indicated for most of the poisons, exceptions being alcohol, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, carbolic acid, acetic acid, etc.

questions.text: An adolescent boy with schizophrenia had witnessed his parents fighting with each other for the past several years. He is overly close with his mother and she convinced him to take her side in the divorce. He always blamed his father for all their family problems. Which of the following best describes the abnormal family dynamics?
questions.solution:
This scenario describes an abnormal family dynamic, where one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender. This is known as marital schism.

Marital schism, marital skew, expressed emotions, and double-bind refer to abnormalities of family dynamics. They act as psychosocial stressors, hampering the adaptive capacity of the individual, thus contributing to the development of schizophrenia.

Marital schism- one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender.

Marital skew- a disharmonious situation where one parent dominates over the other.

Expressed emotions- parents or other caregivers may behave with overt criticism, hostility, or over-involvement towards a person with schizophrenia, which further worsens the illness.

Double bind- a hypothetical family in which children receive conflicting parental messages about their behavior, attitudes, and feelings.

questions.text:
A 32 year old man presents to the casualty with complaints of severe left great toe pain; He has had no such prior episodes. A picture of his left foot is shown below. 
On performing an X- Ray which of the following do you expect to see?

choices.text: Martel’s Sign/ G Sign/ Rat Bite Erosions

questions.solution:
Only Soft - Tissue Swelling will be present in the X Ray of a person with Acute attack of Gout.

The history clearly says he has had no prior episodes and the clinical presentation is that of a clear cut acute attack.

The image shows inflamed great toe consistent with the above. In acute attack only soft tissue swelling will be seen in the x ray.

The other options, Martel’s Sign/ G Sign, Rat Bite Erosion, Joint space narrowing, Secondary Osteoarthritis are all characteristic of chronic gout.

questions.text: As a volunteer at a refugee camp, you come across an adolescent with complaints of difficulty in sleeping and nightmares. Having lost both his parents to cross-firing, and witnessing the arrest, torture, and eventual killing of his elder brother, he now prefers to spend most of his time alone and doesn't interact with others. This disorder is associated with the overactivity of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and is due to abnormally high activity in the amygdala, which makes the patients relive their traumatic memories.

The amygdala is responsible for the genesis of emotion, rating the emotional importance of an experience and activating the hippocampus accordingly. Thus, an emotionally intense experience is imprinted in the memory. As a result, the traumatic memories lead to a state of constant vigilance, even in safe, familiar settings.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Mallampati classification except _______

choices.text: It is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation
Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures
Only hard palate is visualised in Class III
Tonsillar pillars are visualised in Class I

questions.solution:
• Only the hard palate is visualized in Class IV of Mallampati classification.

Mallampati classification is used to predict difficult tracheal intubation based on the size of the base of the tongue.

  • The patient is seated upright with the head neutral, and mouth open, the tongue protruded, and no phonation (Patient should NOT say 'aah').
  • A Mallampati classification of I to IV is assigned, based on the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate.
  • Higher scores on the Mallampati classification indicate poor visibility of the oropharyngeal structures attributable to a large tongue relative to the size of the oropharyngeal space, and, subsequently, leading to more difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

It causes proteolysis of snare proteins. Snare proteins have three components- synaptobrevin, SNAP25 and syntaxin. The snare protein is required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles. Thus it leads to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal transmission.

There are 7 different strains of clostridium botulinum and each strain acts by a different mechanism. Toxins of C. Botulinum A, C and E cleave SNAP25. Type C also cleaves syntaxin. Type B, D, F and G cleave synaptobrevin.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole antifungals are of two types:

  • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. His x-ray is given below. Which of the following statements is correct about the condition?

choices.text: Histology of the lesion shows multi-nucleated giant cells.
The tumor is seen more commonly in children.
Reactive sclerosis around the tumor is always seen.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing a soap bubble appearance is suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT)/ osteoclastoma. The histological finding in GCT would be multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells. 

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years (Option B), with slight female predominance. It is exclusively seen in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones (Option C). GCT is seen most commonly in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT:
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor (Option D).

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like the distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: What is the principle of the test in which the patient is asked to read the chart shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a duo-chrome test based on chromatic aberration. It is used to refine the final sphere in subjective refraction.

The patient is asked to compare the clarity of the letters on the green and the red side. If a myopic sees the letters of the green side clearer, he is overcorrected. So, +0.25 D sphere is added or -0.25D is removed. However, if a myopic sees the letters on the red side clearer, he is undercorrected and -0.25 D sphere is added. With optimal spherical correction, the letters on the red and green halves of the chart appear equally clear.

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: Which drug can be used for pain relief in a patient with the following barium swallow?
questions.solution:
Sildenafil citrate - PDE 5 inhibitor can be used for pain relief in diffuse esophageal spasm.

The image depicts Corkscrew / Rosary bead appearance of the esophagus, characteristically seen in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm.

The pathophysiology of the disease, at least in part, involves inadequate Nitric Oxide(NO) synthesis or impaired Degradation of NO.

Treatment:

Initial Therapy: Calcium Channel Blocker - CCB (Diltiazem)

Tri-Cyclic Antidepressants - TCA (Imipramine)

For resistant Cases:NO Donors (Sildenafil/Nitrates)

Botulinum Toxin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the emergency with watery diarrhea. The diagnosis was made on stool cytotoxin assay. On colonoscopy, ulcers, plaque's and pseudo-membranes were visualized. Patient condition improved drastically after the use of metronidazole. CECT finding is given below. What is the name of the sign seen on CECT?
questions.solution:
The CT image depicts accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

The accordion sign is seen on CT examinations of the abdomen and refers to the similarity between the thickened edematous wall of pseudomembranous colitis to that of an accordion. The appearance arises as a result of oral contrast being trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudo-membranes formed on the luminal surface of the colon.

Pseudomembranous colitis is a severe form of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI), typically caused by prolonged use of antibiotics such as cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin, which disrupt the gut flora, causing a spectrum of disease ranging from watery diarrhoea to fulminant, life-threatening colitis. The bacteria release toxins that damage the colon, causing diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever, and the formation of whitish-yellow plaques (pseudomembranes). Diagnosis is made through stool tests for toxins or bacteria. Risk factors include advanced age, poor hygiene, and gastrointestinal surgery.

questions.text: In which of the following steps does reductional division occur?
questions.solution:
Meiosis I or reductional division occurs in the transition from primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte.

Meiosis takes place in germ cells to generate male and female gametes.  Meiosis involves two stages of cell division, namely, meiosis I and II.

Meiosis I produces two haploid cells. Because the ploidy is reduced from diploid to haploid, meiosis I is referred to as a reductional division. Meiosis II is an equational division analogous to mitosis, resulting in the creation of four haploid daughter cells.

questions.text: Antibodies formed in the spleen that are directed against the cell surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX are characteristically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), antibodies are formed in the spleen against the cell-surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX, causing increased peripheral destruction of platelets.

Clinically, ITP may be divided into an acute form and a chronic form. Both clinical types of ITP are associated with the development of antiplatelet antibodies, mainly against the platelet antigens GpIIb/IIIa and GpIb/IX.

The acute form is more commonly seen in children following a viral infection, while the chronic form is more often seen in adult women of childbearing years. Most individuals with ITP are asymptomatic, but if the platelet count drops low enough, they may develop petechial hemorrhages or epistaxis, usually after an upper respiratory infection.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia. 

Types:

Acute (<6 months) and chronic (>6 months) idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation

questions.text: In a child with a unilateral undescended testis, a diagnostic laparoscopy is performed which showed the blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
In non-palpable testis cases, laparoscopically encountering blind-ending vas deferens and testicular vessels prior to entering the internal ring is sufficient to diagnose a vanishing testis. In such cases, no further exploration is required.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The descent of the testes can arrest anywhere, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
 It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially?
questions.solution:
The above image shows penetrating injury by a metallic fish-hook.

In cases of penetrating injuries, the foreign body is removed only after ascerting it's location through a CT scan.

Hence, Removal of the foreign body is not done initially in these injuries. It is surgically explored & repaired under OT settings.

Management of penetrating injuries of the eye include:

  • Primary survey (Option D) of the patient and the wound 
  • Visual acuity assesment (Option B) in both normal and injured eye 
  • A CT scan is performed to localize the foreign body and detect any intaorbital or intracranial extensions.
  • MRI is contraindicated for metallic foreign bodies.
  • Prophylactic intravitreal antibiotics (option C) are prescribed

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the marked opening?
questions.solution:
The marked opening in the muscular part of the diaphragm is that of the esophagus. Vagus nerve passes through it. 

Oesophageal opening passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm at the level of T10 vertebra.

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
The compound has three ionisable side chains
The compound has one ionisable group

questions.solution:
The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pK1 and pK2 of the compound.

Other options:

  • The points A and B represent the pKa of carboxyl and amino groups respectively.
  • The amino acid has no ionizable side chains as the graph shows only two pKas.
  • The amino acid has two ionizable groups: an amino group and a carboxyl group.

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

Titration curve of Glycine:

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO-.

pK1 and pK2 correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the aminoacid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • The presence of two pKas indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • The presence of three or more pKas indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is referred from a sub-center due to a feeble pulse and low BP. The patient has had diarrhea for 2 days. He has sunken eyes and is lethargic. On examination, BP is 90/60 mmHg. Which of the following fluids cannot be used for resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has severe dehydration which is treated by giving IV fluids. Plain glucose and dextrose solutions should not be used as they worsen the hyperosmolar state.

Intravenous rehydration: Used for initial rehydration for patients in shock or those who are unable to drink.

  • Ringer's lactate solution/Hartmann's solution - Used for injection. Best commercially available solution. 
  • Diarrhea treatment solution- Recommended as an ideal polyelectrolyte solution for intravenous infusion.
  • Normal saline- Used if nothing else is available. It is the poorest fluid, as it does not correct the acidosis and will not replace the potassium losses.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD in a state of euphoria. He was smiling and talking softly when he came in, then he was quiet for a while. He then seemed to be excited and suddenly started to laugh for no reason. How should the psychiatrist record his mood and affect?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the patient's mood is elevated because he seems to be euphoric and excited. His affect is labile because there is excessive variation in emotions without any apparent reason (from smiling one moment, to being quiet, then laughing).

Mood is a pervasive and sustained emotional state experienced subjectively by the patient. It is not always readily observable. It can be characterized as follows:

  • Dysphoric- includes sustained emotional states such as sadness, anxiety, or irritability.
  • Elevated- an exaggerated feeling of well-being, euphoria, or elation.
  • Expansive- lack of restraint in expressing feelings, frequently with an over-valuation of one’s significance or importance.
  • Irritable- easily annoyed or angered.
  • Euthymic- mood in the normal range. 

Affect is the cross-section of mood at a given point in time. It fluctuates with time and context. It can be observed by the clinician. It can be characterized as follows:

  • Quality (or tone) of a patient's affect includes being happy, irritable, angry, agitated, tearful, sobbing, and flat. 
  • Quantity of affect is a measure of its intensity. e.g., mildly depressed or severely depressed.
  • Range can be restricted, normal, or labile.
  • Appropriateness is described in relation to the social situation. 
  • Congruency is described in relation to the thought content of the person.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females?
questions.solution:
DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS. 

90% of DHEA is synthesised by the adrenals and 10% comes from the ovaries.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2.

ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Clinical note: Lithium, which is often used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene.

No water reabsorption

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is:
questions.solution:
The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with postmenopausal bleeding is suspected to have an endometrial lesion. What is the gold standard investigation to confirm her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy is now considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of an endometrial lesion. It is preferred for the initial evaluation of women with bleeding suspicious for malignancy.

Endometrial sampling can be done by hysteroscopic biopsy. It is more sensitive for focal endometrial lesions. Dilatation and curettage may also aid the sampling of endometrial lesions.

Ultrasound, CT, and MRI are adjuvant to other investigations. Diagnostic laparoscopy will be required to study the nature of the tumor and its spread if ultrasound picks up a pelvic tumor.

The image given below shows the procedure of hysteroscopy.

questions.text: Artificial nose in an anesthesia machine is

choices.text: Controls of oxygen flow in the machine
An alternate route of ventilation when the endotracheal tube is blocked
Administration of drugs in case of emergency

questions.solution:
The artificial nose in the anesthesia machine is a heat and moisture exchanger.

  • It is attached between the tracheal tube and the right angle connector of the breathing circuit.
  • These are passive devices which do not add heat or vapor but contains hygroscopic material that traps exhaled humidification and heat which is released upon subsequent inhalation.

questions.text: Correctly identify the tests given below:
questions.solution:
The above image shows the phalen’s test followed by finkelstein test.

Phalen’s test-Here the patient is asked to hold their wrist in complete and forced flexion for about 30-60 sec. If positive-sign and symptoms similar to carpal tunnel syndrome are reproduced. 

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient’s thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating.

Although Finkelstein stated that this test is “probably the most pathognomonic objective sign” of De Quervain's tenosynovitis. It is not diagnostic.

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except
questions.solution:
Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Following ureteral obstruction, there is a progressive fall in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons.

All the other factors/options increase GFR.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows air bronchogram sign in a lung with consolidation, seen in pneumonia, which is supported by the clinical history of this patient.

An air bronchogram is a tubular outline of an airway made visible when there is filling of the surrounding alveoli by fluid or inflammatory exudates.

The causes of air bronchogram are as follows:

  • Lung consolidation
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Nonobstructive pulmonary atelectasis
  • Severe interstitial disease
  • Neoplasm
  • Normal expiration

Pleural effusion is seen as a homogenous opacity on chest radiograph.

The given radiograph shows peribronchial thickening and air bronchogram sign:

questions.text: An ophthalmologist tests a particular phenomenon using the instrument shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the same?

choices.text: The phenomenon is a physiological one
Frontal lobe controls the slow pursuit movement
Reversal of optokinetic nystagmus, in congenital motor nystagmus

questions.solution:
The given image shows an optokinetic drum used to elicit optokinetic nystagmus (OKN). The parieto-occipital lobe controls the slow pursuit component, whereas the frontal lobes control the saccadic component.

OKN is normal physiological nystagmus in response to motion/continuously moving objects. It occurs in response to a repetitive visual stimulus moved across the visual field. The slow phase occurs in the direction of the moving stimulus; the fast phase occurs as a saccadic refixation movement in the opposite direction. In patients with congenital motor nystagmus, a reversal of the OKN response may occur. An OKN response elicited in a person who feigns visual loss indicates that visual input is present and is a malingerer.

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

Options B and C: Kartagener syndrome is also known as  primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of: 

  • Sinusitis
  • Situs inversus
  • Bronchiectasis

Option D: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

questions.text: An​ 8-year-old child was brought with an unprovoked dog bite. Which of the following measures should be taken?

choices.text: Withhold the vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days
Give half the dose of the vaccine

questions.solution:
This child should be given immediate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) by administering a cell culture-derived vaccine to reduce the chances of getting rabies.

Zero by 30 is the global strategic plan to end human death from dog-mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: The Resident asks you to perform Allen's test in a patient before cannulating the Radial Artery. This is because Allen’s test is mainly used for _________

choices.text: Assessment of ulnar collateral blood flow
Assessment of radial collateral blood flow

questions.solution:
Allen's Test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Procedure:

  • The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded and the patient is asked to make a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.
  • Then the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation:

  • As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the colour of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5 – 6 seconds.
  • If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.
  • The modified Allen’s test considers a threshold of 5 seconds.

Clinical significance:

  • In recent years, the studies have shown that, although the Allen test is often used to identify patients at increased risk for ischemic complications from radial artery cannulation, the predictive value of this test is poor.
  • It is also used for identifying patients acceptable for radial artery harvest or use for coronary angiography.

questions.text: All of the following muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except?
questions.solution:
Palatoglossus is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes (hence innervated by the hypoglossal nerve), except palatoglossus, which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vago-accessory nerve.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve.
  • All the muscles of pharynx except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 14 year old male is brought with the complaints of multiple hyperpigmented papules over the face and other sun exposed areas with persistent erythema. He had history of similar episodes since childhood. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched base during DNA replication
Removal of oligonucleotides containing damaged bases by endonuclease
Removal of the altered base by base specific glycosylase

questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. Defect in the removal of oligonucleotides containing the damaged bases by endonucleases is seen in xeroderma pigmentosum.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.  

Important clinical features are:

Intense cutaneous photosensitivity, xerosis, poikiloderma, actinic keratosis, acute burning under minimal sun exposure, erythemas, hyperpigmented lentiginous macules, and malignant lesions in sun-exposed areas, including basocellular carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.  

The final diagnosis of XP can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to ultraviolet radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy and culture of skin fibroblasts.  

There is no cure for XP. Treatment consists of minimizing exposure to sunlight and regular dermatological care, as well as surgery for recurrent tumors excision. Patients should be followed up every 3 months. Genetic counseling is important in a family that has an affected child and is considering having more children.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.solution:
Colchicine inhibits neutrophil (granulocyte) recruitment.

Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerisation of microtubules by binding to tubulin. This reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils, thus reducing the inflammatory response overall.

Colchicine is used in gout and Mediterranean fever.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for genital tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The ampulla of the fallopian tubes is the most common site for genital tuberculosis.

  • Ampulla is the most common site.
  • Intramural part is the least common site.

questions.text: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II?

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.solution:
Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.

The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.

The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6. 

Uses of MHC/ HLA typing include:

  • Anthropology
  • Transfusion
  • Paternity testing
  • Forensic science
  • Transplantation
  • Disease correlation

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with persistent unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge which is blood-stained. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
In a child presenting with persistent unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, which is blood-stained, the most likely cause is a foreign body.

Foreign body can cause unilateral nasal obstruction and subsequent superimposed infection which causes malodorous discharge. It may often be blood-stained. 

Option B: Atrophic rhinitis usually starts at puberty and mainly presents with nasal obstruction and foul smell from the nose. Epistaxis occurs only after the removal of crusts.

Option C: Epistaxis is a rare manifestation of polyps.

Option D: Unilateral nasal angiofibroma also presents as painless, progressive unilateral nasal obstruction, often associated with epistaxis and rhinorrhea. But it is more common in the adolescent age group.

questions.text: Positive quadruple test for Down's syndrome will show all of the following results except _________
questions.solution:
Positive quadruple test for down syndrome will show decreased MSAFP (not increased).

Quadruple test is the second trimester measurement of maternal serum alpha fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG and inhibin-A. It is done between 15-20 weeks.

The abnormalities seen on quadruple screen are tabulated below:

 

Trisomy 21

(Down's syndrome)

 Trisomy 18

Neural tube defect or Abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Low Normal

Dual Test is done in the first trimester while triple and quadruple tests are done in the second trimester.

Changes seen in Down's syndrome are:

Dual test Triple test Quadruple test
Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased
PAPPA decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
  MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased
    Serum inhibin increased

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of ____________.
questions.solution:
A variety of hydrogen peroxide gas–based processes that use plasma as part of the sterilization process are known as "plasma sterilization."

The mechanisms of antimicrobial action in these processes are primarily due to hydrogen peroxide gas (or condensed gas) and not plasma, although the plasma generation phase of these processes is known to assist in the breakdown of residual peroxide in the chamber load.

questions.text: You notice a baby with Dermatomal cicatrix and atrophy of the affected limb. Which of the following infections in the mother is it characteristically associated with?
questions.solution:
Dermatomal cicatrix with atrophy of the affected limb is characteristically associated with the maternal infection of VZV.

Cicatrix is seen clinically as zigzag scarring, in a dermatomal distribution, and is associated with the atrophy of the affected limb.

Many infants with severe manifestations of congenital varicella syndrome including atrophy and scarring of a limb have significant neurologic deficiencies. In some cases, there may be neither skin nor limb abnormalities but the infant may show cataracts or even extensive aplasia of the entire brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactant?
questions.solution:
Albumin is a negative acute phase reactant while haptoglobin, ferritin and C-reactive protein are positive acute phase reactants.

Acute phase reactants are classified as positive and negative based on whether their levels decrease or increase in inflammatory states.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of oligomenorrhoea, weight gain, and acne. USG shows multiple cysts in the ovary. Which of the following is not included in Rotterdam criteria?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and acanthosis nigricans is not included in the Rotterdam criteria.

PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman but the cause is unknown.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE - 2018) is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). It is an algorithm and diagnosis is made only after excluding other causes. To diagnose both of the following criteria should be present:

1) Irregular menstrual cycles is defined as

  • normal cycles in the first year post menarche (due to pubertal transition).
  • < 21 or > 45 days in 1-3 years post menarche
  • < 21 or > 35 days or < 8 cycles per year > 3 years post menarche to perimenopause.
  •  > 90 days for any one cycle > 1-year post menarche
  • Primary amenorrhea by age 15 or > 3 years post thelarche (breast development).

2) Clinical/Biochemical hyperandrogenism characterised by alopecia, acne, hirsutism

If only one of the criteria can be established, then an endovaginal/transabdominal ultrasound to demonstrate polycystic ovaries should be done (confirmatory).

PCOS can increase the risk for:

  • Cardiovascular disease 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Gestational and type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man had recently joined a gym to improve his physical health. He attempted to lift a 30 Kg dumbbell but developed sudden pain in his right arm. He came to the casualty with an abnormal bulge over his arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following tendons is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Popeye sign, which is seen in the proximal biceps tendon rupture.

Popeye sign is seen on flexing the elbow. An extremely prominent bulge of the muscle belly occurs as its unrestrained fibers contract.

The proximal biceps tendon makes up 90-97% of all biceps tendon ruptures. In isolation, it has little effect on the upper limb function but produces a characteristic deformity called the Popeye sign.

Note:

The 4 most common areas of tendon rupture include quadriceps, achilles, rotator cuff (most commonly supraspinatus), and biceps.

questions.text: In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within:
questions.solution:
In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within 72 hours.


If a doctor does not maintain the medical records of the patients for a period of three years as per the regulation, and refuses to provide the same within 72 hours, when the patient or his/her authorized representative makes a request for it, then it is professional misconduct.

questions.text: In precipitation reactions, excess of antibodies causes _____
questions.solution:
In precipitation reactions, excess of antibodies causes pro-zone phenomenon.

Marrack's Lattice Hypothesis was proposed to explain the mechanism of precipitation. 

According to that when multivalent antigens combine with bivalent antibodies in varying proportions,precipitation occurs in the zone of equivalence.

  • Pro–zone phenomenon: It is caused by excessive antibody in the test system.
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigen and antibody are in optimum proportion.
  • Post–zone phenomenon: Presence of excessive antigen in the test system

questions.text: The given cell is a ______ and the perinuclear halo is due to ________
questions.solution:
The image shows a plasma cell, and the perinuclear halo is due to the Golgi apparatus.

Plasma cells are typically spherical or ellipsoid with basophilic cytoplasm. A perinuclear halo (also called a hof) is a classic feature of plasma cells - contains the Golgi apparatus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor?
questions.solution:
The major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor is endothelial cells.

vWF is also found in:

  • Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells
  • Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies
  • Subendothelium - binds to collagen

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
questions.solution:
The cook is most likely to be carrier of Staph. aureus.

The onset of food poisioning with in 4-6 hrs of food is mainly due to:

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Bacillius cereus (has no carriers)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Area marked A is Broca's area (44, 45) and is present in the inferior frontal gyrus
Area marked B is the visual association Area (17, 18) and is present around the calcarine sulcus
Area marked C is the motor association area (5, 6) and is found in the superior parietal lobule
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (8) and is found in the middle frontal gyrus

questions.solution:
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (8) and is located in the posterior part of the middle frontal gyrus. It controls the conjugate movements of the eyes. It is connected to the visual part of the occipital cortex. 

Lesions here cause loss of horizontal conjugate movements.

Visual association area (18,19) (B) Present surrounding the striate area Correlation of visual impulses with memory, recognition of objects seen, and depth perception Visual agnosia. 

Primary visual cortex (17)

 Around the post-calcarine sulcus Reception and perception of isolated visual impressions of color, size form, motion, illumination, and transparency Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
