5 and 7 - Sensory association area Superior parietal lobule
8 - Frontal eye field Posterior part of middle frontal gyrus, anterior to the facial area of the precentral gyrus
44 and 45 - Broca’s(Motor speech) area Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

41 and 42 - 

Primary auditory area

 Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus(Heschl’s gyrus)
22* - Wernicke’s(Sensory speech) area Superior temporal gyrus
17 - Primary visual(striate) area Walls and floor of the posterior part of calcarine sulcus (postcalcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe

18 and 19- 

Visual association area

 Remaining part of the medial and superolateral surfaces of the occipital lobe
28 - Primary olfactory area Anterior part of the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus
43 - Gustatory(taste) area Inferior part of the parietal lobe, posterior to the general sensory area of the mouth

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but  rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B.

This is a case of visceral leishmaniasis, and it presents with fever associated with rigor and chills. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are common. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, but in the Indian subcontinent, it is rare. 

Diagnosis is by ELISA and the indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

Medical Therapy :

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
  • If initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used.

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice.

Other drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis include: paromomycin and miltefosine.

Other options:

Option b: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

Option c: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA  and related infections.

Option d: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth, had HR - 120 with a slow, irregular respiratory effort. There is some flexion of extremities, grimace and cyanotic limbs with a pink body. The APGAR score would be:
questions.solution:
The APGAR score will be 6.

2 - HR - 120

1 - a slow, irregular respiratory effort.

1 - Some flexion of extremities

1 - Grimace

1 - Cyanotic limbs with a pink body

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: In women when Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG) decreases because of insulin resistance or androgen excess, the unbound testosterone concentration is increased and leads to hirsutism. This lack of regulation is because

choices.text: Bound testosterone levels is the regulator of reproductive axis not the unbound form.
Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis
Testosterone is a weak stimulator and hence a large variation is required in its levels before eliciting a response.
Unbound Testosterone gets sequestered in adipose tissue.

questions.solution:
Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis.  

The increased unbound testosterone level does not result in an adequate compensatory  feedback  correction because Estrogen, not testosterone, is the primary regulator of the reproductive axis. So, when SHBG decreases because of insulin resistance or androgen excess, the unbound testosterone concentration is increased, potentially leading to hirsutism.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management?

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fetal compromise. The management in this patient is immediate termination of pregnancy. Since this pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks, it can be terminated by cesarean section.

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

  • Reduced end-diastolic flow indicates uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
  • Absent end-diastolic flow suggests fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.
  • Reverse end-diastolic flow suggests impending doom of death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. They represent a new class of oral anticoagulant drugs that do not require monitoring.

This group of drugs inhibit factor Xa in the final common pathway of clotting [conversion of Prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa)]. They are given as fixed doses and have a rapid onset of action.

Oral direct factor Xa inhibitors are indicated in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?
questions.solution:
Based on the agglutination test shown in the image, the blood group is O positive.

As agglutination is present only in 'Rh' and not with 'A' and 'B' hence the blood group is O Rh positive.

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over MacConkey agar for the culture of organisms in case of  UTI because:

choices.text: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus
It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria
It promotes the growth of pseudomonas

questions.solution:
CLED (Cysteine lactose electrolyte-deficient) medium is preferred over MacConkey agar for the culture of organisms involved in urinary tract infections because it is less inhibitory and promotes the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except β hemolytic streptococcus) and candida. 

A combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar is used for the processing of urine specimens. CLED medium is used as an alternative for this combination. It can also prevent swarming of Proteus, and is thus different from blood agar. Like MacConkey agar, it differentiates between lactose fermenters and non-fermenters. Lactose fermenters change the colour of the medium from green to yellow. However, these two facts are not the reason it is better than MacConkey agar for evaluation of UTI.

questions.text: The surgeon asks for suture material to close the median sternotomy wound post successful completion of a CABG surgery. Which suture material would you give him for the sternotomy closure?
questions.solution:
Surgical steel is used in the closure of sternotomy wound.

Surgical steel:

  • It is a non-absorbable suture material and is made up of an alloy of iron, nickel, and chromium.
  • It is available as monofilament or multifilament,
  • Tissue reaction is minimal
  • Tensile strength is infinite (> 1 year)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male diabetic with CCF under treatment was started. A week later, he complained of a yellow hue in his vision. He was treated for tuberculosis 8 months back. What can be the probable cause(s) for this symptom?
questions.solution:
Yellowing of vision (xanthopsia) can be an early indication of digoxin toxicity.

It can also be an adverse effect of thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide). Sildenafil use can characteristically lead to cyanopsia.

Antitubercular drug, ethambutol: can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green colour blindness

Note: Hydrochlorothiazide can cause hypokalaemia (especially in the initial 2 to 3 weeks, and thus warrants monitoring during that period). Hypokalaemia, hypercalcemia, hypernatremia and hypomagnesemia can precipitate digitalis toxicity.

Also, calcium administration in a patient with digitalis toxicity is avoided due to a risk of an irreversible state of global myocardial contraction (stone heart syndrome).

questions.text: Which of the following diseases cannot be diagnosed by Tzanck smear?
questions.solution:
Hansen's disease is diagnosed by slit skin smear for acid-fast bacilli using the modified Ziehl-Neelsen technique.

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

Tzanck Smear findings Disease
Acantholytic cells Pemphigus, Hailey-Hailey disease
Degenerated necrosed keratinocytes Toxic epidermal necrolysis
Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, Bullous impetigo  
Multinucleated giant cells Herpes simplex virus 1 and 2, Herpes zoster
Henderson-Patterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum
Leishman-Donovan bodies Leishmaniasis
Clusters of basaloid cells Basal cell carcinoma

     

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders 
Pemphigus Vulgaris Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells)
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola Acantholytic squamous keratinocytes , eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion called a "Guarnieri body"
 Leishmaniasis Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodiesgrouped together in a typical "swarm of bees" fashion, within large macrophages (Wright's cells)
Bullous Impetigo Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with abundant neutrophils and clusters of coccoid bacteria
Genodermatoses 
Hailey-Hailey disease Multiple acantholytic cells; Direct Immunofluorescence Negative
Darier's Disease "Corps ronds" are isolated keratinocytes with a round shape and an acidophilic cytoplasm. The corps grains are seen as small, hyaline, acidophilic ovoid bodies resembling pomegranate seeds.
Cutaneous Tumours 
Squamous Cell Carcinoma Atypical Squamous Cells
Basal Cell Carcinoma Clusters of Basaloid cells

 

Image : Tzanck smear , showing three multinucleated giant cells in center.

questions.text: A 25 year old man involved in a fight, injured his finger and the deformity is shown in the following image. X-ray is normal. The most appropriate management at this stage is:

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.solution:
Based on the mechanism of injury and the deformity characterized by flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint, along with a normal radiograph, the likely diagnosis is mallet finger, which is managed by splinting the finger in hyperextension.

Mallet finger, also known as baseball finger, occurs when there is a sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint, causing avulsion of the extensor tendon from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx.

The terminal joint is held in a flexed position, and the patient is unable to straighten it. However, passive movement of the finger remains normal.

As it occurs due to soft tissue injury, a radiograph will not show any bony abnormality, unless it is associated with an avulsion fracture.

Mallet finger without bone injury is treated with a plastic splint, keeping the DIP joint hyperextended for eight weeks, followed by four weeks of night splinting.

The following image shows splinting of the mallet finger:

Surgery is considered only if there is a large fragment (>50%) and subluxation of the DIP joint.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus, which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother?
questions.solution:
On finding a congenital heart block in the fetus, the mother should be evaluated for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Fetal and neonatal heart blocks occur due to myocarditis and fibrosis in the region between the AV node and the bundle of His. Congenital heart block primarily develops in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens, and up to 50 percent of women with SLE test positive for these antibodies. So in pregnancies with either of these antibodies, fetal cardiac monitoring is performed between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation.

The cardiac lesion is permanent, and in most cases, a pacemaker is required. Maternal hydroxychloroquine therapy is associated with a reduced incidence of fetal heart block, particularly in women who have previously had an affected child.

Neonatal lupus erythematosus is thought to be caused by the transplacental passage of maternal antibodies. It is characterized by skin lesions known as lupus dermatitis in newborns, as well as various hematological and systemic abnormalities. In some cases, congenital heart block may also occur. Thrombocytopenia and hepatic involvement are also seen. 

The most common cutaneous finding in neonatal lupus erythematosus is an erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin (raccoon sign/owl eye/eye mask). The eruption can be exacerbated by UV exposure. The rash improves over the first few months of life and usually resolves without scarring by 12 months of age.

Avoidance of sunlight should be advised and low‐potency topical steroids may be of benefit.

The pregnancy outcomes are best in women with:

  •  Dormant lupus activity for at least 6 months before conception
  •  No lupus nephritis manifestation in the form of proteinuria or renal dysfunction
  •  Absent anti-phospholipid syndrome or lupus anticoagulant 
  •  Superimposed preeclampsia does not develop

questions.text: Two studies were conducted. Study A had population as the unit of study. Study B had healthy individuals as the unit of study. Study A and study B are ________ and ________ respectively.
questions.solution:
Study A is an ecological study since in ecological studies population is the unit of study. Whereas study B is a field trial since field trial involves healthy people as unit of study.

Type of epidemiological study:

  1. Observational study
    1. Descriptive studies (hypothesis formulation)
    2. Analytical studies (hypothesis testing)
  2. Experimental studies/Intervention study (hypothesis confirmation)
Type of epidemiological study Unit of study

Analytical studies (hypothesis testing)

    
  • Cohort study/Follow up study
 Individual
  • Case control study
 Individual
  • Cross sectional study/ Prevalance study
 Individual
  • Ecological study/Correlational study
 Population

Experimental studies (hypothesis confirmation)

  
  • Randomized control trial/ Clinical trials
 Patients
  • Field trial
 Healthy people
  • Community trial
 Community

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).
